reviewText:
This game is awesome. And free. Get it.

Timeline of Events:
-Start off with sorry excuse for ship. Literally a cargo crate with a thruster
-Realize you are in massive debt
-Slave for hours making petty cargo runs between worlds
-Havn't made dent in massive mortgage
-Buy another cargo crate with thruster
-Double average income
-Break 'J' key, buy new keyboard
-Pay off massive Mortgage
-Do more cargo runs
-Buy bigger ship
-Start transporting people instead of cargo
-Run out of gas in middle of nowhere
-Get raided by pirates
-Buy warship to protect you from said pirates
-Discover that looting pirates is much faster money than cargo runs
-Buy more warships
-Attempt to take over a pirate planet
-Get bodied
-Buy more warships
-Break 'J' key, buy new keyboard
-Start main quest line
-Holy crap this storyline is awesome
-Get bodied by the Republic during main questline
-Accidentally discover alien sector of space
-Sell everything for shield beetles
-Decimate Republic with new sheild beetles
-Finish main questline
-Wow that was awesome
-Discover the quarg
-Try to capture quarg ship
-Die
-Try again
-Die
-Repeat previous steps over and over
-Buy more shield beetles
-Spend life savings on ship modifications
-Finally defeat quarg ship
-Use quarg technology to destroy everything
-Take over galaxy
-Break 'J' key, buy new keyboard

In all seriousness, this game is amazing. I highly recommend you try it out, it is free after all!

reviewText:
So I land on a plant and check the space port for any missions and I wind up with a woman holding gun to the back of my head. It gives me two options, one is raise my hands like a smart person and the other is Do a karate move". I kind of just stared at the screen for a couple seconds before clicking the "raise my hands" option. The woman with the gun tells me to move or something and two choices pop up again. "Comply" or "Now do the karate move". I stared at it. And it stared back. For what seemed like eons I watched it. It was seducing me. It was corrupting my morals and everything I hold dear. I wanted to stay in the immersion but it did not care what I wanted. It wanted me to click it like Miley Cyrus wants attention.

I clicked it and she went off on a rant about how she's a she-badger.

10/10 best dialogue ever

reviewText:
NOTE: This is a very old review. I have also been negatively involved with the developers and parted ways with the project since then, so I will not do a followup review as I think I would be unfairly biased. You should probably go look for more recent reviews than this one.

Endless Sky is a straight up ripoff (with several excellent additions) of the Escape Velocity series - and that's a good, even great thing.

Cons:
- Economy is static, not dynamic like in EV
- I'm pretty sure the ships just fly around; they don't affect the economy either. For example, you can't ever clear a sector of pirates; new ones will always spawn to take the old one's places, sometimes right before your eyes
- Enemy AI is incredibly stupid; I've had pirates with only missile launchers chase me down even after they expend all their missiles, which means I get a free kill
- It is definitely possible, especially early in the game, to get auto-ganked by huge mobs of enemies as soon as you take off from a planet, before you even have a chance to see what awaits you in space. Since there's no skill, just dumb luck, this is quite frustrating for people like me who try to get through games like this without save-scumming as much as possible.
-Besides the rebel plotline, it's really hard for me to find any of the other plotlines. I had one other plotline offer, but I was really hoping to ally with the Republic and I have seen no offers from them at all - which sucks since you need their military license if you want to buy their ships.
-There are no pirate-customized ships on sale, even on the worlds that explicitly say they are for sale.

Pros:
- Combat pacing is perfect
- Progression feels good
- Visuals are a step up from EV:Nova
- Autopilot for landing, shooting, and multi-jumping is very good
- The balance between speed, power, and heat means there's a lot of thought to put into customizing your ship
- Customization of your ship is properly encouraged within limits; it's possible to have a millenium falcon" type ship
- Ship boarding actions are hugely improved from the EV series
- Game is in a very stable and efficient state already
- Mortgages and Crew mechanics are a great addition to make management of your liquid assets more complex
- Fleet commands are of course a welcome improvement
- There's plenty to explore and even late into the game I feel like there are more secrets that I will uncover with proper detective work
- Game is open-source
recommended:
and fully cross-platform. It doesn't get better from a licensing standpoint.

The Weird:
- You never have to pay for fuel. At all. Yet much of the economy is apparently based around deuterium fuel processing. This makes zero sense
hoursPlayed: but I'm not yet sure whether it's a good or a bad thing for gameplay.\n- You seemingly can't buy any equipment to improve the quality of your long-range (on map) scans\n- Events happen
voteText: but I've yet to see any planets trade hands even when factions are at war. The game FEELS very static.\n- Every action takes exactly 1 day. You have no option to spend more days on a planet
helpfulPercent: just to use up time
votesHelpful: and no matter how long the jump is
votesTotal:
every hyperspace jump takes 1 day.

The Wanted:
- A news feed
- Distinction between privateers and pirates; faction-aligned privateers only prey on certain non-faction ships
- Dynamic
votesFunny: persistent economy - ships should have real lives

column19: and the planets should spawn new spacecraft at a given rate depending on their population.\n\nWonderful game with a long
column20: long future ahead of it."

reviewText:
As an avid Escape Velocity Nova fan, and having played through it several times, along with many of it's smaller and larger mods over the years, I can say this is a lovely clone.

Please note: This review is mostly intended as a comparison to the Escape Velocity series. If you do not know this series, much of the information here won't be as relevant, but should still give good insight as to what kind of game it is.

For the sake of comparison I will be using a Pro's and Con's list.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pro's:
*Gameplay has been made significantly smoother compared to the EV games.

*Travel is a breeze now;
-Landing is done automatically.
-Jumping through multiple systems only requires a single command.
-You can initiate a jump from anywhere in the system.
-Simplified controls.

*The dialogue, port info and item descriptions are well written and fit in perfectly.

*A treasure of content in terms of places to visit, ships to encounter and buy, outfits to use and secrets to uncover.

*You can have a LOT of ships in your fleet.

*You can outfit every ship in your fleet seperately.

*Once in space, everything seems to be real-time. Meaning that a fleet jumping to another system can be found back if you follow them there, and your own ships can be several systems away while you are jumping" ahead of the pack. (You can avoid this by holding the jump button.)

*More advanced
date: better boarding mechanics with more options and actual finiancial risks
recommended:
such as "death benefits" you need to pay when a crew member dies.

*Simple but lovely graphics.

*It's obvious
hoursPlayed:
but still worth mentioning: It's absolutely FREE!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Con's:
*Occasional typo.

*Sound effects could be better. The dev has this high up on his priority list
voteText:
however.

*No music. Great opportunity to put up your own tunes though.

*Currently only the "Free Worlds" main plot is available
helpfulPercent:
meaning story-wise the game is quite limited. I believe the dev is still working on more main plot lines.

*Lack of a Bar or something similar.
Edit: The Space Port acts as the Bar

you buy or capture ships. (I see this as an improvement as you can customize your own ships.)

*Doesn't seem like taking a loan will ever be worth the costs.
Edit: It's worth the costs when using the money to buy more or bigger freighters

reviewText:
This is just the sort of game I have been looking for, for ages.
Very reminiscent (for me) of the original Elite on C64 only in 2D.
I love space exploration games, and this one has struck a chord.
There is not really a sense of urgency, and you can play at your own pace.
Great time sink and if you die you don't have a huge grind because the game
saves your progress periodically when you land on a planet/station.

I have already logged more hours on this game than many of the other P.O.S. indie games
out there (with trading cards!!!) that I actually forked over good money for (O.K. well not good money,
but on discounted sale, but I hope you get my point).

This game was obviously a labour of love.
Seriously Michael, why are you not charging for this masterpiece/gem/diamond in the rough?
If at all possible, at the very least let people know how they could donate via paypal or other means to support you and any other developments you may have in the pipeline, you deserve the spoils of this wonderful game.

reviewText:
Well....what can I say about Endless Sky?

First, the game is free but thats does not mean this game is bad or is pay to win or something like that, literally Endless Sky is free, no need to pay for anything, you just download the game and start playing.

Second, this game is open world, you can anywhere you like and the star map is huge, there are lots of star systems you can visit, some are inhabited some refuse to let you land because of faction issue, still I have to admit it, its a huge world to explore in Endless Sky.

Third, the sense of progression in this game is awesome, you begin with a small ship, either a shuttle, a small freighter or an interceptor, you first have to pay the debt you have for buying your first ship.....so need to do missions until you finally finish paying everything....then comes the hard part....choosing another ship, maybe now you want to test the shuttle or maybe try to fight space pirates? well better get more money and buy a new ship. The sense of achievement of buying a new ship is great.

Fourth, difficulty (this may be a con for some people), this game has no mercy, if the game wants you death, it will spawn either a pirate flotilla or just a well armed pirate ship in the system just to destroy you.....yes this game is difficult as you dont know what to expect when entering a new system or leaving a planet, there is always the possibility of being  ganked by pirates. This game is steep learning, you get better at the game by trial and error.

Endless Sky is a great game, if you like space games, you are going to love, also if you are looking for a singleplayer free to play game, this game is for you.

9/10, try it!

Timeline of Events:

- Buys a bunch of upgrades to ship and 3 fighters for the built in hangar bay on my warship
- Goes back down south, hunts pirate frigates and warships for 10-15 million apiece
- Net worth is now 150k million
- Dies near port, tries to reload game
- Ship is gone forever due to corruption of save file
- Downloads recently released Star Wars mod, starts anew

reviewText:
If you have ever played a game from the X-Series, you kind of know what awaits you. Just in 2D.
You fly around between Star systems to either trade goods an make a Profit, take missions to deliver certain goods or passengers or fight the countless pirates (or become a pirate yourself).

+It's free!
+nice variety of Ships and equipment
+can easily provide more entertaiment that some games for 20 bucks
+It has a ~10 hour storyline
+great moddability
+no microtransactions and the only (and free!) DLC is a high resolution texture pack

+-the entire game is a grind for more money and better ships, but that is just how this kind of game works

-the tutorial is rather barebones, which also is quite common in this genre

If you are unsure if this game is for you, just download it (just ~40mb) and give it a try, it's free!

reviewText:
I love this game!

First off, it's free and has no microtransactions! YAY!

The game itself involves traveling around the Milky Way (our galaxy) doing one, or more of the following things:
1) Trading goods
2) Transporting people
3) Piracy

I haven't tried being a pirate yet, but it sounds like fun!
Something to note is that you have constant volocity - to slow down, you must turn around and propel yourself that way.
I haven't had to use the combat yet, but you can either have guns or turrets (or, probally, both). Guns work by pressing 'TAB' to fire a shot in the direction you are facing, I can imagine that being quite awkward to use. But, I assume turrets allow you to fire in any direction, not just the one you are facing.

There are so many mechanics to this game that I couldn't even begin to describe them all, so, if I were you, I'd just give this game a go - It is free.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played, and I cannot recommend it highly enough.  Really fun and VERY addicting, doubly so, as it is free.

Here are some tips for the game:

-DO NOT BUY THE FIGHTER AS YOUR FIRST SHIP: if you do this, you will die a lot until you get used to the gamestyle
-Follow the storyline for a bit to get used to gameplay
-Buy a Mule and a Raven as soon as possible: a small fleet of these is great for quick earning and good defense
-You do not need more than 3 Bactrians at most, as long as you stay in human space
-Shields are more important than anything else, and with good shields, you can just ignore pirates
-Despite what it may seem like the first time you die you DO respawn at the last world you were on
-ALWAYS look for good trade routes, even if it takes time
-NEVER attack a pirate  planet unless you are very sure you can win

That's about it.

Again, really fun game, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
So, I'm going to give this a positive recomendation, though I'm not super excited about the game and it is understandable if you pass it up. I'll explain why.

The short is: It's well put together for the most part; combat is little awkward but mostly avoidable. It is free, but seems to lack an end-game goal.

Oh, and if you do start, get the Cargo ship first. Consider the others once you're out of debt. In the Trading screen, hold Shift, Ctrl, or Alt to buy/sell multiple items at once.

The long is:

First the good stuff:
Price: I don't know their intent with the game, but it is free. I've not found any kind of microtransaction BS, so it is completely free. Hard to argue with that.
Few bugs: I shouldn't have to count this as a good point, but with the market as it is...
Autosave: VERY frequent. Should the game crash or you get killed, it will send you back maybe a minute or two of playtime.
You can build a fleet of ships, rather than just having to upgrade one giant ship. There is some control in the orders you give. I still recommend only having a fleet of very big ships, and sticking to one ship until then.
It isn't hard to build up money after the early game.
Everything has a 100% sell value. So if you buy stuff by mistake, it just costs you a second to correct it. Goods change value by planet, but equipment and ships don't, so buy and sell those wherever.


The bad stuff:
Mouse control for direction and shooting is unavailable, but would have been nice (I'm thinking like SPAZ).
Your fleet isn't good at staying near you if they are freighters. So don't buy small ships for your fleet, they are pirate bait. Big ships can at least survive long enough to resolve the situation (regroup and kill, run away, land on planet, etc).
It is very easy to miss the storyline (I did) when trying to make a quick buck early on.
The economy doesn't evolve. Values in each system stay exactly the same. While this does make things easier, it also removes any incentive to find new trade routes when you have a good one. This also means the jobs don't really evolve, so the stuff you see early on is all that will be there.
Each solar system feels tiny. You warp in next to the planet, and... that's pretty much it. Everything happens within sight range of a planet, so each system feels tiny, and all systems feel identical when you're flying around.
You start in debt. I realize this is part of the point of the game, but it feels weird having that weight hanging over our head for so long when jobs pay very little.
You can't switch between piloting different ships in your fleet.


The game doesn't seem to have an end goal, so you kind of have to set them for yourself. Ok

reviewText: The perfect free game Endless sky is massive, emmersive, free and of course; So much fun it will blow your mind! You are, from the get-go, given 3 main choices of ship (think Pokémon starters) that will shape this game in it's entirety for you. People mover Cargo ship or Fighter (Easy, Intermediate & Hard respectively) And each adventure is fun and dangerous in it's own way! This has a gargantuan map as well as lore description for every planet and their spaceport Which you should always check and it is incredible!!! There is so much love and time put into this game it is a wonder that it is free, games with nowhere near this amount of content can cost $20 or more, and this game is free: no in-game store, no Endless Sky+ and no subscription fee! reviewText:
Endless Sky  is a very simple-economy simulation game.  Basically your general buy low and sell high principle with missions and a couple other factors.  This makes the game very easy to pick up and enjoy within the first 10 minutes which is a luxury you don't have with most games.  It's not the prettiest game I've seen, but the low spec requirements make it playable on any system.


Pros: -Decent economy sim
-Large variety of planets and solar systems; the map is huge
-Some customizability for space ships (weapons, engines, etc.)
-Can be addicting
-Simple UI

Cons: -Not enough customizability with ships, both aesthetically and functionally
-Tedious at times, sometimes it feels like nothing's really happening.  You have to grind to get the necessary money to purchase bigger and faster ships, whether that be by destroying other ships or being a merchant.
-Annoying animation when you make the jump to another solar system.  Rewatching the animation, though it's only 5 seconds, can become irritating after a while. I realize that that's nitpicking a little, but it'd be nice to be able to skip that animation.


All in all, it's definitely worth it to check this game out.  It's a good game to kill some time, and best of all, it's free :) I haven't explored all the features of the game yet, which I suppose is a good thing! There's a ton of potential with this concept, and I'm interested to see what the developers can do to make this game even better.
voteText: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Definitely a 'Yes' review here.

There are two spiritual successors to Escape Velocity that I know of.  NAEV and Endless Sky.  NAEV has some people doing a great job (also a great game), but with much slower development.  Endless Sky is very polished, very content rich and has a lot of UI features none of this line of games ever had.

Endless Sky is the kind of game I'd have made if I had the motivation and energy.  The fact that it's moddable is just fantastic and I hope it encourages a number of interesting mods in the future.

I often spend small quantities of money trying out games on steam and didn't even realize until revisiting the store page that this game is FREE.  Holy cats.  I'll need to post a donation to the game devs.

Good things:

1) The turn based boarding mechanic is a wonderful way to add an interest to boarding operations without it consuming much time or interfering with the central feel of the game play of piloting a starship.

2) Good ship progression.  I see some complaints of a slow/humble start.  I did experience that a bit.  The game does reward doing fun things like combat and piracy and tends to discourage focusing too much on trade or missions.  Once you get over the hump you start moving right along.

3) Better shield regen is VERY nice for things like demanding tribute from planets.  In the old EV games, particularly Nova, it reached a point where your shield regen was basically how fast you could kill ships and you spent tons of time kiting and waiting.

4) Kiting is less rewarding.  The ships turn and lose interest and often come at you at different speeds forcing more variety to how battle large fleets.  You're more likely to duck in and out of engagements with heavy ships and pull back to lick your wounds.  Also anti missile prevents waiting out long barrages of missiles.  A good improvement on EV style combat mechanic all around.

Suggestions:

1) Battleships are god tier.  I tried so hard to make a lighter more maneuverable cruiser work, but in the end just wrecked everything with a shield beetle.  Probably hard to tweek the balance at this point, but it'd be fun to be able to get by on being 'dodgy'.  I'll keep trying a bit.  Not ruling it out completely yet.

2) The lock on mechanics aren't great.  It uses a selection of always choosing the closest ship rather than selecting from what you facing or cycling through promising opponents (if re-selecting within only a second or two try a different ship than selected).  So that annoying fighter behind you robs your lock from the ship you actually want to strike.

3) You can lock a target and spin to face it automatically.  I'm less into that.  I'd like to be forced to maneuver and fire with my perhaps my turrets and guns veering towards the target to the degree that each is able.

4) Command points (ala Sword of the Stars) would be AWESOME.  As your notoriety grows or perhaps through some other means gain the ability to command more vessels and otherwise have a sort of fleet limit so that you have to be choosey with your ships used for end game content.  Perhaps a maximum of 6?  I see a lot of posts of people accumulating masses of shield beetles with shield regenerators to keep them alive and then enough weapons quantity to contribute to your killing.  Might be cool to limit that a bit.  Maybe command points are vastly more generous/more efficient for smaller ships as well?  Maybe you can have only one Heavy Cruiser as a command ship and all the others must be lighter?  Might need a good end game medium vessel to compensate that had some survivability.

reviewText: If you loved Escape Velocity back in the day, you'll definitely want to download this game. Even if not it is free, and while not full of polish it is full of features. Trading system gives you immediate feedback on your potential for profit or loss both at your immediate port based on what price you paid for goods, and you can check the star map to see profit margins relative to your location at distant ports. Mortgage system and crew salaries have been implemented so that they add to the immersion without feeling overwhelming. Star map seems well fleshed out, and the game is full of customizations. All before taking the potential for new content people can make with the provided tools which just adds onto the value of an already free game. You really can't lose giving Endless Sky a shot.\n

reviewText:
Product received for free

So, Endless Sky is a pretty special game. Not in the gameplay, really -- which is a better-than-average spacefaring sandbox game -- but in the way it is presented. It is entirely open source, meaning the code is available for anyone to view or alter. This makes Endless Sky important because it provides an outlet for aspiring modders or even game developers to mess around with an already functional game in a low-risk environment. Honestly, I hope that some day soon this game makes its way into schools for introductory game development classes.

10/10, bravo to the developers, and kudos to them for making this free. I'd have paid at least $10.
voteText: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Endless Sky is a great game. It might not seem like much of one at first glance, but it really pulls you in once you start playing. It's a lot of fun running missions and generally trying to figure out how to make more money and do more things. I especially liked the non-intrusive and responsive tutorial at the start - the game as a whole really shines through its writing. I'm still enjoying running deliveries across the galaxy, so I can't vouch for the entire storyline, but the fact that there even is one that blends into the world so well is very impressive.

I feel that the controls and mechanics could be more friendly - arrow keys were a surprise, as was the fact that ships in the 31st century don't have retrograde thrusters, and that you have to turn 180 degrees and thrust to stop. It's also a little jarring that you can simply jump into a sector to be absolutely demolished by a pirate cruiser, though loading from the previous save makes it no big deal.

All in all, this is a great game and I recommend it whole-heartedly, especially since it's free AND open source. The developer did a great job on this.
voteText: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I don't write reviews often, mostly because they get buried anyways, but this game is pretty darn good. Especially for something that's free.

The main premise of the game is you take out a loan to buy a space fairing vessel of your own and have galactic adventures. There is a bit of plot, so if that's your thing, go for it. You don't have to, you could just trade or be a pirate or whatever. As long as you pay off your loan and don't get killed, the game doesn't care where you go from there.

It has quite a bit of detail built into it, with a fair few planetary descriptions and such to give lore freaks a bit of juicy goodness. There are a lot of ships that you can buy, although you'll have to save for a while before you can even think of buying another.

It's also open source, so members of the community can have a field day making whatever world they envision. It's really got a lot of potential to become something special.

tl;dr: It's free, it's like 50mb (At time of review), try it.

reviewText:
Where Rebel Galaxy dissapoints me this little gem does everything right. Trade goods, transport passangers, fight pirates or the militia and equip your ship for your own needs: Everything feels right. You're planning your routes to optimize the different missions with deadlines and fuel management.
You even see how much profit you make on the galaxy map with every good on every port you've visited so far.

Even the story is more realistic: You lend 500k from a banker, buy your ship and pay your debt, while an retired captain is introducing you to the game with little missions.
The galaxy has a lore and events happen around you, giving you the feeling the galaxy evolves and there are often little side quests that are well written, too.

I'm shure i miss a lot more since I haven't played a lot so far but you should really try it if you love space games of every kind

reviewText:
This is like the best spacegame ever. and it's free.... just play it already.

Combat is rather simplistic and akin to SPAZ, though without the directional damage part, but the number of different weaponsystems is definitly comparable. however pirating can be quite alot of fun when local forces don't blow up an incapitated ship right infront of you. (single fusion core is worth 5M that is even in the late game a nice payout)

Economy is static so you easily make millions with a single 2way traderoute and you can largely automate that because preplanned jumproutes get continued automaticly.

however the big selling points (of this 100% game....) is the writing and the outfitting

lots of different weapons and utilites, engines, etc tinking around if an atomic engine, a regular engine or an ion engine is the best choice, all with different sizes, thrust values and energy requirements. which weapons fit best, additional fuelpods to increase jumprange, ramscopps to collect fuel on the way standard efficent jumpdrive or a more fuelhungry fast jumpdrive everything is available. also pirate stuff like anti sensor plating, smallarms, nervegas (illegal across human space) cargo scanners, etc, etc, etc

and the writing is simply superb. with lots of interesting and engaging sidequests and an epic mainquestline with LOOOOTS of plottwists.
also a couple of very interesting alien species with completly different tech and ships, some of which can be acquired troughout the main questline, some has to be captured though piracy.

all in all i got more enjoyment out of this game than out of most of my fullprized games... without any prize.

Steps to successfully mastering this game:
1. Make an account

12. Realises that destroying pirate ships is fun.
13. Tries to board pirate ship, gets stuck in the middle of space, because of less crew.
14. Realises that you can sell pirate parts.
15. Gets much more powerful ships.
16. Realises there are aliens in this game.
17. Tries to attack Quarg, they vanish without a scratch.
18. Realises there are other ways to travel rather then hyperdrive and scram.
19. Starts to look for more info.
20. Discovers special parts and many more alien races. Also discovers modding.
21. Makes an impossible to kill ship, destroys everything.
22. Gets quarg ship parts.
23. Gets bored and tries to add own storyline, systems and ships.
24. Captures the entire galaxy
25. Feels like an old, retired man who once used to fight in small, fast ships. Almost forgotten the sensation of dying in the middle of space
26. Starts all over again
27. You were too busy reading you didnt realise I switched from explaining steps to telling my own story :P

reviewText:
If you have played Escape Velocity, skip down one line

If you have not played Escape Velocity, then play Endless Sky and imagine that there was a similar game in the 90s.  Wow.

Enjoy an experience that is everything that was loved about Escape Velocity while being entirely unique.

Now realize that any part of the game can be modified just by adding simple to understand text files and standard .png images into a plugins folder.  WHAT?!  Anyone can be a game developer with this game!  Not only is it so easy that anyone can do it, but once you've mastered the easy parts you can delve into more involved aspects of modification that can act as stepping stones to learning an actual programming language.

It's not just a game; it's a tool to realize dreams.

reviewText: A great free game. I'd have gladly paid at least $5.00 for this. It's worth about that much in the current state alone with all of the stuff you can do in it. It can be monotonus but that's entirely up to you. You can start out doing missions and build up cash to get a better ship, attack a pirate (Or even a friendly trader) to scavenge parts for money or even take the ship itself, run travelers around, trade. I mean it's basically a single player top-down Elite Dangerous. Very very very fun. The cap of the game seems to be getting a sizeable fleet and maybe either claiming entire worlds for yourself or just demanding tribute from them. Either way I've dumped about 12 hours into it and I just have a relatively tough mid-tier freighter with about 10mil saved up and the ability to actually put up a fight against pirates. It has enough content to keep you busy and honesty you can't argue with free.

reviewText:
In the mid-90's there was a game called Escape Velocity released by Ambrosia Software, where you flew around in spaceships in a 2d universe, completing economic or combat based missions. I recieved a copy free copy of this game on a MacWorld Magazine disk and was immmediately hooked. I spent endless hours of my youth exploring the the Escape Velocity univerise. It's an open world, where you follow quests and decide which faction you were going to join and others that you were going to become enemies with. You could join the Confederates, Rebels, Pirates, or just remain an independent trader.

Endless Sky is clearly modelled after the Escape Velocity series (Escape Velocity, Escape Velocity Override, and Escape Velocity Nova) and anyone who was a fan of those games should be playing this.

That being said, for me personally, Endless Sky brought back a lot of nostalgia from my gaming days in the 90's. Growing up I had a Macintosh computer, which really limited my computer gaming choices. There were the early Bungie games (Pathways Into Darkness, Marathon, and Myth 2) as well as Blizzard's Warcraft and Starcraft games. Bungie, Bllizzard, and Ambrosia Software were my three go to gaming companies and they all sparked my passion for gaming.

Enough nostalgia, let's talk about the game. You start off with a trading ship and have to complete several trading missions in order to pay off the morgage you got for your first space ship. As the game goes on, you begin to explore the galaxy, earn more credits, learn more about the main plot, and eventually build and upgrade your ship. There appears to be one main storyline to this game (as opposed to the EV series where you followed a certain faction's story line) but you can go about it at your own pace. Some side missions pop up which also add an element of intrigue. All the missions require you to either take people/cargo somewhere, to fight other ships, or analzye something. At both the beginning and end of the mission there are no cutscenes but instead you read and sometimes make decisions on what was said.

The combat is a bit difficult to get used to at first and you'll need to buy another ship and upgrade a bit before taking anyone on. The first few hours playing this, not unlike my high school days, I always got my ♥♥♥ kicked. If you keep grinding out the trade missions, you'll soon have a ship to be reckoned with and can go face to face with everyone who wronged you. Also you can hire a fleet of ships to help fight along side you although you'll have to pay them x amount of credits to retain their services.

I've played this game for several hours and it has kept me entertained and curious on how the story line will unfold. It's not ground-breaking at all, sometimes I got lost trying to figure out where the story picked up at, and the game is outdated graphics-wise but I'm recommending it.

I'm also looking forward to the user created mods. Escape Velocity had a similar editor where there were a lot of great user created mods released for free and kept the game new and exciting after you exhausted the original game.

If your curious, give it a shot. You got nothing to lose but time - it's free.

reviewText:
Four words: The game's simply amazing.

Space/Shooter games were my favorite, even since my childhood. Blasting down other spaceships? A blast. Flying around? Speed of sound? Definitely mindblowing. And all the other stuff I didn't even mention? Awesome.

For the record, I'm simply amazed by the way it's played: trading, exploration, combat, you name it. And the fact that the game's highly moddable, makes it stand out even more. I'm just mindblown, mindblasted, just so addicted, and there's all that. It's so addicting that I play until midnight, that it comes to be a bit of a problem.

And there's a few problems to name after describing how good it generally is. Frankly, I'm hoping for more storylines. Because there's only one storyline: Join the Free Worlds, Oppose other factions, etc. And doing that takes mid-heavy grinding and effort. Getting cash is hard, and downright tedious. Your mortgage payment is heavy, and otherwise pressingly cash-burning. And those are some problems to name. Worst of all of them, is the fact that there's only ONE joinable faction. The one storyline only allows you to join the Southern World Pact/Free World Pact. And that's just it. Stay a merchant, or join the Free Worlds. And it's just so sad, you can't start off joining the Republic/Navy and reach out for becoming a patriot, protecting the galaxy. I've always been thinking they'd been the major faction you can only join... But it's not.

Overall, this game erupts with fun. The game is free to play, and as soon as you start playing, you're just about to start a voyage, an adventure within the galaxy. So, what if there's a few problems? I still enjoy the game itself.

Nonetheless, it's definitely a BLAST.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review covers version 0.8.1.1, released January 27th, 2016.  I'll be making dated additions to this review because the game is still in development.

Endless Sky is pretty amazing if you can find the main plotline.  After I found it, the mysteries and plot twists kept me coming back.

The game takes place in the far-future of humanity.  By the year 3013, humans have colonized a great deal of the galaxy.  You, as the player, have always wished to head into space and pilot your own spaceship.  Unfortunately, not long after your dream begins to come true, a horrible catastrophe makes galactic civil war almost certain.

PROS:Autosaves between planet landings, you NEVER lose your ship permanently
Autosaves before vitally important plot choices
Snapshot-style save system: you are able to redo quest choices over-and-over by saving before making a choice
Quick response time when controlling your ship
(Nearly) unlimited potential ship configurations (weapons, engines, shields, etc.)
Attractive planet graphics and planet surface photographs
Many planets to visit, all with various kinds of political and social climates
Plot twists and unsolved mysteries
Anyone can make suggestions and potentially help to add content to the game: https://github.com/endless-sky
Even if you don't want to add any official content, mods are always welcome
Helpful community
CONS:Not many detailed side quests in addition to the main storyline
Repetitive gameplay
It's possible to miss the main storyline for a long time, if you don't explore the right areas of the galaxy
Of the three faction-based main storylines proposed, only one of them is currently 100% complete
EITHER: (aka. points that may be +/- depending on your likes/dislikes)Gameplay takes place entirely on a 2-D plane
All of the plot is text-dependent
This is a one-dev project, he has the final say-so on changes made to the game; but he also takes good suggestions seriously
This game is a work-in-progress
Overall, this game is what you make of it.  You can play the role of pirate, bounty hunter, renegade defender/pirate ship looter, rebel, or just a simple merchant/transport captain.  If you're stuck, there's a kind community around this game that's willing to help.

I'm looking forward to what the future holds, because Endless Sky (so long as it's being developed) can only get better!

reviewText:
SOO overpriced!  I just spent a whole day playing this and I couldn't put it down - such a huge time investment!  :)


Anyways - this game might have sold me on 2D game development being superior to 3D (focus on gameplay rather than 3D spacial arrangement).

There's a really good learning curve.   I felt great satisfaction when the lights come on how some part of the game works.

Then there's the futzing".  Futz futz futz.  I can stare at a ship build and go back and forth and back and forth "1 of these or 2 of those or 3 of the other?" trying to tune the ship to work *just right*!  Its comparable to Star Ruler's ship building screen
date: only here you have to fly the thing and it feels that much closer to the metal.\n\nYou start play with a bank loan which will sap all the money you make.  There are ways to "hide" the money and miss loan payments but then your loan size increases due to interest.  Anyways you come right out of the chute with your hair on fire
hoursPlayed: and it is really satisfying to get the loan paid off.  It felt "grindy" during that phase of the game

reviewText:
Product received for free

Have you ever played Wing Commander: Privateer[en.wikipedia.org]? Or, let's go back even farther than that. How about Taipan[www.taipangame.com]? Um, no??

Get this game; it's a lot simpler than Privateer in mechanics and graphics, and slightly more complicated than Taipan. Still an enjoyable trading game, though. Some gaming concepts never get old. Just be sure that, when jumping through multiple hops along the space lanes, you stop and refuel. It's truly embarrassing to reach your destination and not be able to land because the planet scrolled past you too fast and you couldn't select it, and you can't maneuver your ship because you have no fuel.

Yeah, you know what I mean. Been there, done that, right? right?
(Am I the only one who's done that??)

Edit: Added URLs to the two games referenced above, for those who fall into the Um
date: no??" category. You don't know what you've missed. And thanks for the upvotes on this review. No
recommended: really. Thanks.\n\nAnd it's free. What's not to like?"

reviewText:
Addictive.

1. Start the game and have no idea how to do anything.
2. Figure out how to do things.
3. Get the hang of completing transport or shipping missions.
4. Learn how to gauge your hyperspace fuel and not get trapped in uninhabited systems.
5. Scrape by to pay off your initial loan.
6. Now the money comes flying in because it is ALL yours.
7. Buy some more ships.
8. Wonder, what else does this game have to offer.
9. Continue to be addicted to a game that doesn't cause your PC to crash.
10. Watch those free hours pile on and feel good that your didn't spend any money to burn away all those hours playing this.

FUN!  Light mental work figuring out how to maximize your gains.

reviewText: On my third run of this game, I thought I had everything figured out. I was making a bit of money on top of paying off my mortgage by transporting goods and people (mainly tourists) around the galaxy. In the middle of a couple of jobs, I landed on a planet in what seemed to be a quiet system with no ships in sight. I checked the job board on this planet hoping to find a small job to complete on the way, but considering my almost full cargo, I wasn't surprised. I then departed from the planet to find myself in the middle of a massive firefight with ships almost 10 times the length of mine. I quickly intitalised the jumpdrive autopilot, praying that I would be able to escape. There was nothing I could do as one of the pirate ships noticed me and fired a couple of missles at me. I was dead in less than 2 seconds after taking off from the planet.\nThis game is brutal, but I kinda like it. Worth a shot without a doubt.

reviewText:
This game is far more fun than you'd expect someone's free-to-pay pet project to be.  Much of what story currently exists is admittedly sparse and largely only in place as a means of pointing you in the direction of your next target but it has some interesting lore and side missions already and the potential for much more.  What's more, the game gets updated relatively frequently.  New ships & new equipment, bug fixes, new features, new worlds, new races to meet -- basically whatever the developer can come up with and find a way to integrate.  Add to that the incredible ease of modding (all you need is wordpad) and the game offers considerable time sink potential.

If you ever played the X Universe games then you've got some idea of what you can expect here.  Basically those but scaled down, easier to run and played from a 2D, top-down perspective.  How you persue your career amongst the stars is pretty much entirely up to you.  Maybe you want to establish a flotilla of trade ships and rake in the credits.  Perhaps you'd like to someday command a fleet of fighters from the bridge of your own cruiser (or even carrier, if you play your cards right and your luck holds out) and make earn a living hunting bounties & bringing law to the lawless pirate sectors.  Or, for that matter, maybe you'd like to assemble that fleet and pillage the core worlds.  You can make a decent living off of piracy once you upgrade from one-man fighter craft and, with a sufficiently fearsome reputation, you can even demand regular tribute from the worlds upon which you prey.  Or maybe you'd just like to pilot your own lone, cozy little shuttle craft -- maybe upgrade to a fancier cruise liner down the road -- and just ferry people & small shipments of goods from world to world and enjoy a simpler experience.

All in all, it's hard to decry a free product for not meeting a minimum standard and yet the developer decided to hold himself to one anyway.  Given the short download time, you won't even be out an afternoon if it fails to grab you.  If it sounds at all like something you could enjoy even just putting an hour or two into here and there then there's really no reason not to grab a copy for yourself.

reviewText:
I've had this game for only a few days, and I've played for almost 48 hours.

Granted, I've had it running in the background for some of that, but the point stands.

This game is great.

Pros:
Still in development - you can talk with the developer and suggest improvements
This also means new content is coming out regularly

Solid gameplay - this game just feels good to play. The ships range from tiny to massive, and their handling changes as well. Great selection of stuff to customize with that forces you to balance heat, power generation, and ship handling with the amount of weapons or cargo you want to carry.

Interesting world: this game has a LOT of lore to dig into if you want to find it, or you can just take it as it is. up to you.

Easily moddable: I haven't installed any yet, but mods take the form of plugins that you just place in the appropriate folder, and its designed for you to be able to change things easily.

Open source: You can help make this game.

Low system requirements: anyone with a PC can play this pretty much

Cons:

Only one minor downside
Still in development: while there are benefits to a living game, one of the downsides is content with some loose ends to be filled in later. This also means there are a few minor bugs here and there. If you're reading this after 1.0.0 then this will probably be  a non issue, so download this awesome free game.

Any other issues I've had are already on the list to be fixed, so don't worry about that.

reviewText: It's an interesting game. A nice mix of combat, exploration, and non-combat jobs. So, when starting a new game, you get a choice between a Shuttle, a Star Barge, and a Sparrow. CHOOSE THE STAR BARGE. While all three are pretty sucky and wimpy, the Star Barge is your best bet for earning the money for something better. Don't be tempted to get a Sparrow. It looks awesome, and it's designed for combat... or is it? It will easily be destroyed, and has little cargo/passenger space. So get a Star Barge, pick up the highest paying jobs available, and run like hell if a fight breaks out. You will, eventually, get the funds for better ships. So just hang in there. When you get the chance, I suggest buying a Behemoth class heavy freighter, and outfitting it for combat. You'll thank me later, as it is good at almost anything you'll need a ship for.

reviewText:
i had personally only played (and thoroughly enjoyed) the original Escape Velocity.  With Endless Sky, i've burned virtually all of my free time since discovering this game last august.

there are some who compare this to EV:Nova or EV:Override.  they are correct in their assertions that this game is not them.  this game isn't even a complete EV.

incredibly brief history lesson:
a complete 'Escape Velocity' was released in 1996.  some people got together, and for *two years* put together a new galaxy - using fundamentally the same engine.  *FOUR YEARS LATER* yet another evolution is released.

Endless Sky is not even a complete release, let alone an added six years of re-development.

my imagination has been fired, and i've created a plugin to add more depth to the content already available.  play the bare bones that are available, and you may even find it in yourself to contribute as well.

look for the google group - there are those that will help you bring your story to life, if you're serious.

great game - can't wait for more content (so i'm working on some myself, and helping others do so as well)

reviewText:
The moment I saw screenshots, I will admit I was hesitant. This game, however, has gone above and far beyond my expectations.

Im definitely the kind of person who loves freedom within a game, as well as a rich detailed story and a colourful, thick and fleshed out playable world, and Endless sky does not dissapoint, with story missins eating away hours of my life that I'm very glad to never get back, and diverse and very unique little features that allow me to keep coming back for a daily fix of fleets, explosions and battles galore. the best thing in my personal opinion is that you are instantly allowed to choose a route of play, but then must evolve this play style or switch it up completley to keep up with the the evolution of the galaxy!

the only real con that stands out to me is that it's very confusing as you begin the game, and the possibilities are quite daunting to new players, especially when there aren't really any solid guidlines passed a (extremely) basic tutorial.


8/10

reviewText:
If you loved Escape Velocity Nova, then you'll probably settle for Endless Sky, considering it is free and EV Nova is still $30.

I recommend this game because it plays 'like' EV Nova, but there are just so many things still missing. The ships are all cool looking, but they are just flat 2-D images rather than the dynamic, quasi-3D ships in that 'other' game from 20 years ago.

Another issue I have is how busy things get on the screen sometimes. Like, really, lots of things happening to the point that I don't really know what I'm looking at. It all morphs together into some kind of mashed up light pattern.

There are other problems, but I still recommend this game.
Plus it's free, so you don't have to worry about Captain Hector showing up to ruin your fun.

I've been looking for a new open-world space adventure for a while, and I couln't be happier with what I found.  I've played it for 40+ hours now and I havn't even started the main quest.
Awesome game if space exploration is your type of thing. the main storyline it's pretty neat and doing that opens up alot of the game.

I randomly saw this on the front page of steam, then I saw it was free and was surprised! But moving on to the review and overall experience. But before getting to that, check out the Endless Sky site, it has good info you'll want to know when playing!

easy review:
Pro:
+A large universe
+Plenty of ships to choose from
+Plenty of shenanagins to get into (mostly fighting, escorting, and trading)
+Definitley effort in describing each planet and lore (there are even holidays and events that happen on certain dates!
+Moddable (right down to credits in a text file if you dont want to spend hours trying to get out of debt, but thats part of the fun! .... unless your a cargo/people carrier?)
+Can be a sandbox if you want. (Not forced to do story missions)

Con:
- Sound effects could really use work (beam lasers and thrusters especially)
- Lack of music (but that is what the steam music player is for?)
- Uncommon graphical glitches (for my AMD graphics card at least). Extremely minor, just a flicker of a color (green or blue) for an instant, probably happens about once an hour?
- Start off in massive debt (opening story), interest is very unforgiving. (not necessarily a con, but it makes it a rocky start).
- Combat and flying takes getting used to (it feels awkward to me, as opposed to most other space games, I honestly thought it would feel closer to something like Starfighter: Disputed Galaxy)
- Capturing ships is stupidly costly (Losing a single crewman and you are already paying 1/3 of the ship's worth, by the way, death benefits is calculated using the SHIPS WORTH, which is really really stupid and frusterating.)

Sory of my experience:
You start off taking a loan, a HUGE loan to buy a ship, you get to choose from a passenger ship, a cargo ship, and a combat ship. I personally chose the Sparrow. Named it the Capt. Jack Sparrow" (the ship type was literally Sparrow) set off on an adventure and doing what seemed like tutorial missions with that guy heading off to retire! (good pay)

Quickly realize I am getting milked dry from the ship mortage interest rate of 0.4% a DAY. Each system warp is a day
date: every time you land on a planet is a day
recommended: You have to make a good bit of profit to get out of debt! Choosing missions that are close and pay enough you get more money than you lose to make the trip (funnily enough escort missions are best for that to me!) Best part about escort missions? Who needs to fight? You can just spin up that hyperdrive with "J" and run like hell! Just watch all the bystanders and the navy mobilize to outright OBLITERATE any pirate who happens to give you a hard time! Ever seen a pirate dumb as bricks chase after you to the Sol system? I'd say you will
hoursPlayed:
but he would be too busy dying within seconds! You wouldn't even get a chance to see his ashes! Tons of laughs for sure.

*much questing happens*
Finally made it out of debt! .... now what? Left directionless I just kept doing escort missions
voteText: saved up for a new better interceptor class ship! Bought myself a Beserker
helpfulPercent: instantly fell in love with it as opposed to my Sparrow!. I dubbed my new ship the S.S. Biscuit.\n\n*Some Escort missions later* Finally done enough to get better scort missions! Now instead of getting 15
votesTotal: 000 credits per escort
votesFunny: I now get 60
commentsCount:
000! however the ships turn like whales and are average sized freighters.

*To be Continued* The story goes on ...

P.S. They have a "cheat plugin" with tons of credits and all tech (Ships?) in human space. Enjoy.(for you sandbox lovers)"

Sunk twelve hours in yesterday, and today looks to be much the same.

Endless Sky is pretty complex for such a simple-looking game.  Love the flavor text for all of the planets, the ship customization is pretty robust, and I love the fact that you can basically play the game as you wish.  If you want to run trade routes, shuttle passengers or fight pirates, or do a combination of all three, it's up to you.  And the fact that you can completely ignore the story if you'd like is an added bonus.  Sometimes I just feel like amassing as much cash as I can manage without worrying about politics.

I can't wait to see what plugins come down the pipe.  And I'm eager to start fiddling with them myself.  They're sure to add a lot of value to a game that's already worth more to me than it's zero-dollar price tag.

Bottom Line Up Front: Be a hero of the people, a captain of industry or a pirate king. C'mon, it's free!

A free game is always worth a look, and almost always worth a few minutes of play. At time of writing, Endless Sky has held my attention for eight hours.

You start out by taking out a high-interest loan from the bank and buy one of three ships - shuttle, transport, interceptor - and you can guess what each is for. I went for the transport because I was channeling Firefly and felt like pretending to be Malcom Reynolds. Once you start, it's time to get to work - that debt isn't going to pay itself!

After the first hour, the gameplay is what it is. Pick up cargo from Planet A and take it to Planet B - sometimes as a mission, sometimes hoping to buy low and sell high, sometimes on a timer. You can even mix it up and carry people or escort ships. Alternatively, you can go hunting for pirates, or be one yourself and raid other ships.

The controls are what you might expect from a 2D space simulator - sluggish. If you've ever played S.P.A.Z. the controls will be familiar (and equally frustrating in a firefight).

The story will automatically unfold at specfic moments when you land your ship, and if you visit the spaceport at each planet you can potentially pick up story missions for one of the various factions in the galaxy or chance upon a unique mission (though it is almost always a variation of what I mentioned earlier). You can pick up jobs from the job board or, as mentioned above, figure out the price of goods at your destination and buy them cheaper at your location for resale.

Put on some suitable music (there's none in game) and use your imagination as to why you care to build a fleet of ships. After all, it's free!

IT'S FREE!!!

And intruiging, though I'll agree with the negative comments that the learning cliff- I mean curve is a bit steep. If this is the first time you're playing a game like this then be prepared for being clueless to what the hell is going on as the bank leeches your wallet dry, Kinda like steam but with no reward.

But if you're looking forward to play X3:Terran conflict but your computer is scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ just hearing the specs required then this is a good alternative, also *ahem*

It's free!

Just do it!

Click that green button!

Just do it!

reviewText: One of those free to play games that you should get not because it's free, but because it's a really fun complete game with no in game purchases, no catches, just a really fun game.\n\nUnfortunatly though as of Nov 1 when I played it, there was a game breaking bug wherein my save game was ruined when much of my ship parts were deleted leaving me stranded.  I managed to fix it by editing the save file however.

Excellent.

I've been wanting a replacement for EV:Nova for a long time. Especially since I believe that the company who made that game is still charging full price for a 13 yr old game.

This game takes everything I loved about that game, and kicks it up another notch. Even better yet, it removes all of the really annoying gameplay mechanics of EV:Nova, and makes it so much more fun. If we're living in a society of hyperspace travel, my ship should most certainly have some autopilot, and why should I have to purchase an extra module just to save the trouble of manually refuling at every port? What kind of interstellar society doesn't have a way to check trade good prices at other ports? With this game, these are quesitons I no longer have.

Endless Sky is awesome.
A big thank you to the creator!

An excellent trading/exploration game, reminiscent of Sid Meier's Pirates.  Feels very well fleshed out for a free game.  At the moment the game feels more concentrated on completing missions than on establishing trade routes (mission cargo is DRAMATICALLY more profitable per ton than regular trade goods).  However, it is entirely viable to play as a cruise ship and carry exclusively tourists, or to play as a cargo vessel trying to make deliveries on time.  Be you a privateer or tradesman, Endless Sky absolutely delivers.

To new players:
1.  Read the player manual.  The tutorial is loose and allows you to be the Captain you want to be, but as far introducing    game mechanics, is a little sparse.
2.  Avoid combat early if you aren't a pirate. Combat is unforgiving.
3.  Use the save snapshot feature.  It is possible to accidentally ruin a game due to autosave in a bad situation.

Areas that could be improved:
1.  Aesthetically, this game is unpolished.
2.  Autosave could be a multiple slot rotation, to avoid the dreaded die-load-die loop.

I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed titles like Sid Meier's Pirates, or to anyone who likes free stuff!

reviewText:
This is clearly a work of passion. The amount of time, thought, and work the dev must have put into this is just fantastic. Though I'm sure it started as a hobby project, it's clearly grown into something more. I never write reviews, but this is a game that truly deserves it.

It's a much more realistic trading/space sim than most others, and this is a good thing, as it gets rid of several annoying problems that often plague such games. For one, exploration isn't a blind dive into potentially troublesome situations since local maps can be cheaply bought to reveal the surrounding area. In addition, you can track prices on other planets without manually visiting them, thereby allowing you to plot trade routes quite easily. The story and lore is done through text. You can read as much or as little as you'd like, but the dialogue is natural and very well-done. The tutorial mission is fantastic, optional, and teaches you the basic controls. The synopsis for each planet gives each character and really does make each feel unique. Banter between ships is rather repetitive, but you're going to get that no matter how many unique lines are written.

The game aims to be flexible, and it does that extremely well. The risk/reward of piracy vs. trading is quite balanced. Losing a ship to pirates early during a risky job can feel devastating (as it should), but it's usually only a temporary setback. Conversely, taking a risk and trying to capture that ship that outguns you can be both a disaster or an enormous bolster to your ranks. The number of times I've said, Oh man
date: almost!" have been too numerous to count
hoursPlayed: they've been accompanied by a feeling of excitement rather than frustration.\n\nThe dev has crafted the game in a way that pretty much anyone can add content or create plug-ins. I'm sure the content of the game will expand by leaps and bounds in the coming weeks. There are occasional bugs
voteText: but you can merely check the dev's github to realize he's still working on them. The fact that this is open-source will mean that these are crushed more quickly than usual as other users can fix them as well. Over 600 commits to git since March 2015 show how frequently the game is tweaked
helpfulPercent: bugs fixed
votesHelpful: and content added. Perhaps the biggest drawback to the game currently is that the sounds are rather basic and there's no music. However
votesTotal: I'd expect both of those issues to be addressed soon enough. I can only hope the dev continues to develop more games
votesFunny: as this is the sort of endeavor that shows the true brilliance that indie games can yield.\n\nLastly
commentsCount: to address most of the negative reviews: if you can't figure out how to play this game
column16: you are legitimately brain-dead
column17: likely incapable of tying your own shoes. Sure
column18: the game doesn't hold your hand
column19: but the commands are pretty basic and the intro tutorial teaches you everything you need to know. "pirates op they kill so fast" - Well
column21: flying into a known pirate haven with a starter ship probably isn't going to go well. Use your brain. So yes

column23: you probably won't like this game. And I don't think that's a bad thing."

reviewText:
Remember folks ...this is a SINGLE PLAYER GAME

Once you log in and start following the quests around space it's easy to think you are part of something bigger.

You'll see players whizzing by, you'll see people engaged in space battles, you'll even see automated chat complaining about pirates and raising cargo costs etc.

It's like watching an Ant colony, you can see lots of things happening but the only agenda that is important is yours

It's also a good idea to check the space port at every planet you land on. The intro quest line will give you the basics but its easy to make the mistake of just buying and selling cargo for your first few hours without knowing that the quests come from the space ports but not every planet has one so keep checking

When I saw this game touted as a FREE spiritual successor to Escape Velocity as I was randomly browsing the store, I nearly spat Surge® all over my Kensington Trackball Mouse®. I never expected someone to try to emulate this Macintosh classic so lovingly, right down to the little ticks on the map to track your missions.

But if this is your first time trying this type of game or you were a big Escape Velocity fan back in the day, you might want to try this out for a bit, then come back a year or two from now. As of November of 2015 it is still a work in progress, what with there being no active galactic economy, a small amount of upgrades and weapons to retrofit your ships with, a map size that could be greatly expanded, no command options for your escorts, and barely any faction events and storylines developed.

But this game is open source! So if you feel like cracking your knuckles and getting deep into the nuts and bolts of it, please do!
A community driven game that has a cult following like this can only get exponentially better with time and I eagerly await it's future development.

This game is quite tough, it is almote a rougelike.

But of course it isn not as the galactic map is the same each time unless you mod it.

Be sure to save often as death comes easily. There is an autosave but you should still create several saves of your own as it is all too easy for pirates to swoop in an blow up some of your transport ships just before you dock/land. (Dock/land is what causes an autosave so you can end up loosing ships just seconds before the autosave happens.... which saves your loss!)

Up to this point I have only managed to get a Mule and still find disabling ships to board them really tough. Would have liked some kind of 'bullet time' to slow down combat as it it a litte too fast and furious (and fatal) right now.

This is a fantastic game for something that is trully free.... kudos to the dev!

Great game! Elite for those who can't handle spinning in 3D flight so well...\n\nI'd love to see more free games, of this calibre, on Steam (though I'm worried that it might open a floodgate for crud).

Amazing casual game. I would definitely buy this game if it wasnt free. It doesnt feel like a free to play with how much depth is in it, and its a tiny download. Really I am quite astonished at its quality for a free game. Would absolutely recommend this game to anyone and I really wish there was a mobile version and a multiplayer...
This is a great game and absolutely Free no micro transactions absolutely free you should definetly get it
All I can say is wow... just try it

Sunk twelve hours in yesterday, and today looks to be much the same.

Endless Sky is pretty complex for such a simple-looking game.  Love the flavor text for all of the planets, the ship customization is pretty robust, and I love the fact that you can basically play the game as you wish.  If you want to run trade routes, shuttle passengers or fight pirates, or do a combination of all three, it's up to you.  And the fact that you can completely ignore the story if you'd like is an added bonus.  Sometimes I just feel like amassing as much cash as I can manage without worrying about politics.

I can't wait to see what plugins come down the pipe.  And I'm eager to start fiddling with them myself.  They're sure to add a lot of value to a game that's already worth more to me than it's zero-dollar price tag.

This game is everything Destination Sol could have been. (If you haven't checked out give it a go) The game mechanics work perfectly with the environment and the interactive text just pulls the whole thing together. 10/10,\nThis has been a transmission sent from space by Wheatley 002

Bottom Line Up Front: Be a hero of the people, a captain of industry or a pirate king. C'mon, it's free!

A free game is always worth a look, and almost always worth a few minutes of play. At time of writing, Endless Sky has held my attention for eight hours.

You start out by taking out a high-interest loan from the bank and buy one of three ships - shuttle, transport, interceptor - and you can guess what each is for. I went for the transport because I was channeling Firefly and felt like pretending to be Malcom Reynolds. Once you start, it's time to get to work - that debt isn't going to pay itself!

After the first hour, the gameplay is what it is. Pick up cargo from Planet A and take it to Planet B - sometimes as a mission, sometimes hoping to buy low and sell high, sometimes on a timer. You can even mix it up and carry people or escort ships. Alternatively, you can go hunting for pirates, or be one yourself and raid other ships.

The controls are what you might expect from a 2D space simulator - sluggish. If you've ever played S.P.A.Z. the controls will be familiar (and equally frustrating in a firefight).

The story will automatically unfold at specfic moments when you land your ship, and if you visit the spaceport at each planet you can potentially pick up story missions for one of the various factions in the galaxy or chance upon a unique mission (though it is almost always a variation of what I mentioned earlier). You can pick up jobs from the job board or, as mentioned above, figure out the price of goods at your destination and buy them cheaper at your location for resale.

Put on some suitable music (there's none in game) and use your imagination as to why you care to build a fleet of ships. After all, it's free!
Within 57 minutes, I became financially free.\n\nNever felt so good in my life.

Only 30 minutes into the game I get attacked by a pirate which demobilizes me. Call for help from a merchant ship, and suprisingly he says Ok no problem let me patch you up". Faith restored in AI. Then 10 minutes later I pass a planet
recommended: I'm being attacked by a pirate". I noped out in less than a second. 10/10 would not pass on the kindness. But overall this game is quite fun if you enjoy traveling to different systems while gaining monies."

reviewText:
When I saw this game touted as a FREE spiritual successor to Escape Velocity as I was randomly browsing the store, I nearly spat Surge® all over my Kensington Trackball Mouse®. I never expected someone to try to emulate this Macintosh classic so lovingly, right down to the little ticks on the map to track your missions.

But if this is your first time trying this type of game or you were a big Escape Velocity fan back in the day, you might want to try this out for a bit, then come back a year or two from now. As of November of 2015 it is still a work in progress, what with there being no active galactic economy, a small amount of upgrades and weapons to retrofit your ships with, a map size that could be greatly expanded, no command options for your escorts, and barely any faction events and storylines developed.

But this game is open source! So if you feel like cracking your knuckles and getting deep into the nuts and bolts of it, please do!
A community driven game that has a cult following like this can only get exponentially better with time and I eagerly await it's future development.
Nice game easy to get into and long play time. Can be slow at the start if you waste your money needlessly.

I grew up playing the Escape Velocity series, and this feels like a modern redux on Nova. The ships feel like actual ships (insofar as a 2D space sim may accomplish) the game is engaging, the hud is minimalistic and with purpose, and the gameplay is amazing. It took me about four hours to get my first ship after the starter, and I played that in one sitting. I have no idea why this game is free, but I think you'd be an idiot not to get it.
Jumped into a system where pirates and the militia were fighting promptly got killed multiple  times before noticing that there was another way to my mission location\n\n10/10

reviewText: LOVE THIS GAME. I really feel like the captain of a ship, who's really earning a living and working his way up. If you die, you die, and it's very immersive in it's own way. From paying off a debt, and being tossed into an unknown world, to being captured by space pirates and forming a platoon of ships, this game never ceases to amaze those intrigued by a deep world of sci-fi adventure.

Right, so there's a bit that's lacking here and there, the variety of weapons and ships, and the quality of graphics is a bit down-graded compared to EV Nova, basically what we have is a pretty solid EV classic, which is perfectly fine and all, I spent countless hours of my youth working my way up from dinky shuttle to a massive fleet of frigates.

Perhaps a second installment in this series is called for, to expand the game elements to include some of the really cool stuff from EV Nova, like warp gates, rail guns, that wormhole that would randomly transport you around the galaxy like a time viking, and a more dynamic universe where your actions can shift the balance between the factions!

If the developer feels up to it I'm sure many people here would love to pay a decent sum for such a game.

reviewText:
I love this game.

There is actually a reason why you have money at the start. You live on a sparsely populated farming planet called New Boston, working in a textile mill. You've always wanted to leave, and have been saving for a Pilot's License since you were fifteen. When you finally have enough, you take out a loan and buy a starship. You have three choices, a cheap shuttle, a medium-priced cargo ship, or an expensive interceptor. From then on, you can modify your ships however you like, and get new ships with unique stats.

Second, it is configurable in plain text, meaning you can go into your save file or the game files themselves and change whatever you want. Creating a plug-in is EXTREMELY easy, as long as you can use Blender and GIMP, or have someone to do it for you (thanks, Positive!) The Steam community is very, very friendly.

The game may be confusing at first, but in the end it is a really great game, for free, too.

This game is fantastic. Even though I don't have a ton of hours, I have started multiple characters just to experience the different ways to play, and it's so fun to develop your character/fleet. Reminds of a 2D Privateer, a few missions can be unforgiving, but overall worth every penny!

It does seem to be missing a bit of content but hey, it's free, still recieving updates and will most likely have some very awesome mods as everything is open source.

The story is pretty good. Everything starts out simple but things take a turn for the woese and then it's just a huge s***storm that's pretty enjoyable.

With that said, when you first make a new character, avoid starting the storyline since you'll die. You should amass a large reserve of cash by boarding and selling ships (it's fairly simple and there is a guide to it).

ALSO: with 16 GB ram, an i7-4790k, and a GTX 970 I had no trouble with fleet sizes below ~200. Once over 200, I had hige frame rat drops and the ingame CPU/GPU monitor typically spiked from 3%/2% to 200-600%/10-20% in very large fleet sizes. Though, I usually had task manager running through this and my ram never went above 4 GB and only 4 of my cores on my CPU were ever being used (not sure if the game uses more than one core but I saw activity on those graphs - could be from something else).

I love this game.

There is actually a reason why you have money at the start. You live on a sparsely populated farming planet called New Boston, working in a textile mill. You've always wanted to leave, and have been saving for a Pilot's License since you were fifteen. When you finally have enough, you take out a loan and buy a starship. reviewText:
A free to play game with solid foundations if a bit barebones.

As I only have a couple of hours in the game, there is a lot of thing I haven't tried yet.
The good:
It's free. You can try it and decide if you like it, without losing anything.
You start off with a loan and the choice of three different ships, after that you are free to do whatever you want. The game offers you a string of tutorial missons which show you the ropes of the basic playstyle of your ship, while gives you some small pointers as well.
You can have an entire fleet of ships which can escort you and you can issue them simple commands.
You can add stuff. While the game is in it's infancy I can imagine there will be a boatload of user generated content to it. And the whole thing should be easy to do as well.

The bad:
Using passenger or trading ships can become boring at first, as you only jump and land, and hope that pirates don't kill you. At least until you get enough money for a lot of ships (and crew) to guard you.
The controls are a bit hard to figure out without checking the preferences menu, and the game only shows them for a short time on the bottom-left corner of the screen. The ships have inertia, so combat needs a lot of getting used to.
The background during flight is rather bland (what else would you expect apart from stars), and the closeness of planets, while useful, make the entire area feel just bland and empty. The game also devoid of music, only having a few sounds for thrusters and stuff, making the game feel slower, so it can quickly become boring for those used to faster-paced games.
The game itself is not really hard if you know what you are doing, but there can be instances of getting swarmed with pirates after take-off and thus dying quite fast, especially when you have only a single ship.
The graphics are dull. Planets only show a single picture above their menu, while ships look like low poly 3d models. This however can be easily remedied with editing, so not that big of a problem.

The game actually have a story and while it doesn't immediately point you to it, it can be interesting. All in all while the game can feel like an empty sandbox with spaceships, made by amateurs, it is solid enough to be enjoyable. And also it's free, with the option to add stuff to it.

TL:DR
Its free, it's small, try it out.

reviewText:
A nice little space trading game in the vein of Escape Velocity.

It's not all that heavily updated-- I used to play a lot of different total-conversion plugins (mods) for the first couple of EV games, and, aside from a few differences in the interface, playing Endless Sky feels more like having gotten a new TC than a whole new game-- but I don't see any reason to consider this a bad thing.

Also, it's nice to see more free and open-source software (FOSS) on Steam.

Now all I've got to do is figure out how to mod in the Tachyonic Fighter from Frozen Heart and I'll be very much set. :D
