reviewText:
It's like EVE Online for broke, socially awkward loners who can't pay their internet bill! (Who, me?)
-- It's free! No subscription required, needed, or existing. If you desperately want to pay money (o_O), too bad. There's no way to donate. :(
-- You can play it offline. Unless you're using the Wi-Fi at your local overpriced coffee shop to play EVE, I don't see why this would matter too much, but hey.
-- No real people, nice or otherwise. No scammers/trade hub spammers or price manipulators, but no amazing clan homies or complete strangers who give you 75 million out of the goodness of their hearts, either. You'll have to decide whether that's good or bad.
-- Gankers are still around, though. Their being NPCs doesn't change anything. Remorseless pirates with serious superiority complexes? Same as ever. If you're playing with self-imposed hard restart... I pity you. Greatly. If you weren't completely insane before you started, you probably are now.
-- No inflated prices, although some ships are pretty expensive.
-- Banks are legitimate and actually trust you enough to give you a loan. Unfortunately, it's impossible to get one big enough to make skipping out and ruining your credit score worth it.
-- There's a story, although I'm stuck at a certain point because my fleet isn't strong enough.
-- Easier ship customization and cooler builds. (Crazy fast? Can do. Extremely hard to kill? You got it. No refueling needed? Quite right. Unscannable cargo hold? Indeed, my good man.)
-- A much more casual, less intensive grind. (Endless Sky + trade route + music + relaxation = Endless Sky zen!)
-- A surprising amount of stuff to explore and discover. While you may say, But I can look at all the ships and outfit items from the Job Board!"
date: those are only buyable ships and items from shipyards in systems that you've visited. So unless you've explored every nook and cranny of this huge galaxy (even the apparently inaccessible bits)
recommended: that's not ALL the things. Nowhere close! There are alien ships available... they're just "not available in stores".\n-- It's open source. https://github.com/endless-sky/endless-sky Something you don't like or want to change? Make a plugin. Something you want to add? Go right ahead. Please. This game needs more! That is
hoursPlayed:
unless you're scared of Git. No need to deny it. I don't blame you.
-- Spreadsheets optional.

TL;DR: If you like EVE Online but hate any of the following:
damage outputs
weapon slots
power and CPU balancing
decimal numbers
feeling like one of the poor and destitute 1%
spending real money
sinking all your free time into a game that

people

then try this game!

reviewText: Unforgiving and strangely relaxing. Obviously created by some people who absolutely loved the Escape Velocity series but wanted a bit more. Super happy it can be modded easily. 9.5/10 would be 10/10 if the sound bits weren't so choppy and harsh on the ears and speakers. I would pay money for this game - the fact that it's open source makes it that much more fantastic. Highly recommended for casual gamers. Anyone who's expecting high quality graphics don't bother unless you've played the Star Control series and enjoyed it.

reviewText:
This is an update of my original review, after having about a week to get to know the game better.

Going to give this a thumbs up with some reservations.

Pros:
1. Can't beat the price.
2. Captures the feel of the old Escape Velocity series extremely well, with some much needed ease-of-use updates (such as being able to tell from the map what a system will pay for a given commodity, something you had to do by memory or with a notepad back in the day).

Cons:
1. Piracy is not a viable option from what I can tell.  Even if you are able to disable a ship without destroying it (not easy in my experience), you only have maybe 3 seconds before some do-gooder tries to help you by blasting your prize into space dust.  If you do successfully manage to board a ship and attempt to capture it, you will very likely lose crew members in the process and end up paying death benefits.  Death benefits are, from my understanding, calculated as a percentage of the captured ship's value so you'll always make some profit if you sell the ship, but it can be too small to make it worth it.
2. Combat itself needs a little work.  Large combats involving a lot of ships get chaotic and if your target is offscreen it can be next to impossible to track them on the minimap.
3. There is a fair amount of grinding in the early game in the form of deliver 12 tons of rubber goods to the Vega system" type missions.  That's true to the original series
date: but it's also not very exciting.  The good news is that if you're smart about it
recommended: that part won't last long.  I've seen a lot of people complain that you start the game with a mortgage on your ship
hoursPlayed: but if you trade intelligently and pick good missions (hint: plan your route efficiently!) you should be able to pay the mortgage off within an hour or so of play.  Once that's done
voteText: you should be able to work your way up to afford a decent ship not long after
helpfulPercent: and that's when things become fun.\n\nIn spite of those problems
votesHelpful: it can be very addictive and will definitely scratch the nostalgia itch for those of us who remember EV fondly from back in the day."
votesTotal: November 1, 2015
votesFunny: true

reviewText:
I agree with all the other praise this game is receiving.  Endless Sky is a great game, overall.

I do have a big complaint, however.  The very poorly done combat system.  I can progress no further in the game because of the endless traffic into each and every star system in the game.  The story mission I'm on needs me to fight 1 ship and steal a part.  Fine.  Dandy.  Problem is even when there is a ship alone (since we're talking random gen, here), before I can possibly disable it and loot, another ship or 2 jumps in.  Then another.  Then more still.  Say some of those ships are friendly?  Doesnt matter.  They blast disabled ships 99% of the time.

0Again, I'm loving this game.  As long as I avoid combat and just focus on resources and being a space trucker, very well done.  This one issue is game breaking from a storyline perspective.  You want to do the missions?  Good luck, brother!

reviewText:
Product received for free

If you have fond memories of playing Escape Velocity (the original Macintosh one, not EV: Nova) then this game is for you.  It's slower paced then games you find today, unless you are brave and want to jump right into combat and ♥♥♥♥ off everyone, but you will die or run a lot if you do that.

If you have never played the original Escape Velocity, then this is as close as you are gonna get without needing a mac emulator.

The premise you start with a basic ship, and through trading, missions and piracy, you slowley upgrade and replace your ship with dozens upon dozens of weapns, engines, systems, cargo holds, you name it.  There is a vast selection of ships to get, either by purchasing or by taking them by force.  You can have a fleet of ships, each one upgradable, you can attack planets and demand tribute (get paid on a regular basis, but be prepared to fight a lot of ships, they will not go down without a fight).
There are several factions with mission chains that unlock unique and rare ships and access to exotic upgrades, you can do these missions, or just take that ship by force.

The biggest selling point of the EV games was their modability.  All you need to completely change the game is a graphics program and wordpad.  With these you create your own ships, edit or create factions, missions, planets, ships, anything.  There have been complete overhauls to the EV games that turned them into Star Wars and Star Trek games, or  entirely unique fictional universes.  Or you can just pimp your own ship.

Best of all IT IS FREE!!!!  As is REALLY free. No BS paywalls, no trials, no microtransactions.  I do not know if it will stay free forever, but as of right now it can be your for the low price of nothing.

Give it a go!

reviewText: Get this game!\n\nBut Why?"
date: you eagerly ask as you trawl through the generic reviews...\n\nWell
recommended:
let me tell you. (Oh and its free so there is honestly no excuse for not at least trying it)

-You are a spaceship captain
-You have a ship
-Your ship has passenger and cargo space available depending on class
-You want money to buy a bigger ship with more guns and bigger cargo bays
-You decide to become either a merchant or a fearsome space pirate
-After two hours of continually getting blown up due to some rather poor pirate lifestyle choices you realise that having a fleet of giant transporters and warships is the way to go
-You need to have enough money to buy the giant fleet of doom that your heart is set on because you are a little captain with a little ship.
-So you start being a small time shuttler and merchant making a slow and small progression offset by the debt you are in from buying the initial ship
-Fast forward 6 hours your fleet is starting to look quite zesty
-Exploring and trading with your mega fleet is now satisfying and you can start muscling in on the other ships trade routes
-You start having the Emperor Palpatine feeling and think the galaxy can bend to your will
-It really doesnt
-You die horribly
-Luckily the game autosaves at each planet you visit (once a minute)
-Catastrophe avoided
-Rinse and repeat until you have lost all social skills in the real world and start communicating through grunts
-Ung grnnn uhhh gummm brrr
-..... grrn 10/10 wndddd unnn agnnn....

"

reviewText:
While this free, open source game has a lot to be developed, it also has a lot of promise.  It's not a pure pile of a free game like many free games are.  It definitely isn't a F2P title relying on microtransactions.  The developer just realized he couldn't devote his life to making this game, and figured crowdsourcing it would be ideal.
I am not far in yet, so perhaps I will be expelling massive frustration once I get to the point of trying to conquer the galaxy, but here's a rundown of what I see so far.

You start the game buying a ship thanks to a hefty loan hanging over your head, which you will spend the early part of the game paying off.  You have three options for a starter ship:
1) A shuttle only good for transporting people around from planet to planet, along with some minor commodity trading.
2) A cargo ship which is focused on hauling goods, and a few passengers.
3) A fighter so you can jump right into combat.  It's transport and trading capabilities are limited, so you'll have to really engage if you want pay off that debt.

It seems like these ships correspond to difficulty settings, easy, normal, or hard.  However, I didn't find much difference in difficulty between the cargo ship and the shuttle aside from the fact that the starter shuttle can jump between one more system than the cargo ship without needing to refuel. Payouts for transporting people seems to be a bit slim compared to payouts for massive hauling.  There is something in the game about illegal goods, but I have yet to discover them, or maybe I did and just haven't been discovered hauling them, yet.

Presuming you don't pick the fighter, the early game is about learning which systems need which goods and trading back and forth to rack up money so you can pay off that debt, and to acquire more ships.  One of the nice things is that you can acquire a second ship in your fleet rather early, with the debt still hanging over your head if you like, or just upgrade your ship to the next tier.  You'll need to hire extra crew to pilot extra ships, but that's far cheaper than the debt you are paying off.  Truth be told, the early game is really boring for a while.  It's just pick up a job/quest, buy some cargo, jump to the target system, sell cargo, repeat, with a lot of freedom in how you choose to make your money.  If you happen to run into some pirates, they'll likely destroy you, and you just reload and try again.

There is a story to follow, with only one campaign completed at this time, but progressing through the story is a bit random.  It requires you to land on certain planets in some sort of order, but I am not sure which planets or what order that is.  But hey, the game is open source.  If you want to see more depth, you are welcome to contribute to completing those other campaigns.
Another thing to do early on is explore all of the systems, so you can map out the galaxy and plan your routes easier, however many planets will sell you a local area map which eliminates some of that exploring for a fairly low price.

Though it bears no resemblance at all to FTL (no entering the ship and micromanaging crew details), I feel it would make for a decent roguelite and I have been playing it as such, deleting my profile every time I die.  Ironically, that is more enjoyable for me, in spite of the fact that the early game is so repetitive.  Not sure why.

All in all, if you don't mind unfinished projects, and like the idea of being an intergalactic merchant, there's very little reason to not give it a try.

reviewText:
Its basically a 2D version of EVE,  but without the boredom and complicated UI.
(...or even think of it like a multiplayer version of Space Pirates and Zombies, if you've played that.)

Tons of ships, tons of stuff to put in the ships, hundreds of planets to explore and trade and hunt and pirate and get blown up and spending the first few hours of your life paying off the loan to the bank for your starter ship.
NPCs everywhere, doing thier own thing.

My only gripes -
- I'd like to see a mining system
- I'd like to see a slightly more robust chat interface.  People move too fast to click on and hail.  Also theres so many freaking ships its hard to tell who's human or NPC.

I've only sank a few hours into it, and i'm already in love.
Also its free and opensource.
..and only like 30MB.
DO IT.

reviewText: This game is basically a free version of EV Nova- obviously the two games are identical, but the overall feel is. Endless Sky is very addicting, but it soon becomes a little too easy to generate income and purchase the most expensive ships and equipment. reviewText:
Pros:
-Damn fun to play and fly around. I chose to start as a trader, and it's really easy for me to take on 20 missions at once and keep getting missions as I fly around completing them.
-The descriptions and the detail put into it is great.
-The idea of it being open-sourced and available to modify is great. I haven't tried it yet though.

Cons:
-A bit of a confusing interface, and limited controls. When one of my fleet ships was disabled, I couldn't figure out how to repair it for a couple of minutes. I ha to beat off around 7-8 pirate attacks while I was trying to figure it out. A lot of those more hidden mechanics could be more obvious.
-It's very confusing on what is mounted onto your ship, what isn't, and how each module affects the ship stats. I largely have only bought ships and put an extra cargo area on them. I'd reccomend putting a seperate window on the right side that shows the ship slots, and as you change modules, it also displays the changes in stats.
-The game seems (so far) pretty limited to small fights and trading. It would be neat to have more space in between planets, allowing for ambush attacks and whatnot instead of jumping into a sector and immediately knowing whether there are enemies there or not. Things happen incredibly fast, and most of the time I die before I even knew I was taking significant damage.
-After the short tutorial storyline, apart from a couple of things happening in the galaxy, I haven't been able to find the main stroryline again. Some subtle hints as to where it is would be nice.
-Please, give me more control over my fleet's ships. I have had so many times where we're extremely far away from a battle, yet one of my ships insists on firing it's missiles and wasting credits.

Conclusion: I hope that this is not the end of development for this game. It feels complete, yet still missing a lot of potential. If this was paid, I wouldn't reccomend people get it unless it's extremely cheap, but as it's free to play, I would say that there's no harm in trying it out.

reviewText:
While this free, open source game has a lot to be developed, it also has a lot of promise.  It's not a pure pile of a free game like many free games are.  It definitely isn't a F2P title relying on microtransactions.  The developer just realized he couldn't devote his life to making this game, and figured crowdsourcing it would be ideal.
I am not far in yet, so perhaps I will be expelling massive frustration once I get to the point of trying to conquer the galaxy, but here's a rundown of what I see so far.

You start the game buying a ship thanks to a hefty loan hanging over your head, which you will spend the early part of the game paying off.  You have three options for a starter ship:
1) A shuttle only good for transporting people around from planet to planet, along with some minor commodity trading.
2) A cargo ship which is focused on hauling goods, and a few passengers.
3) A fighter so you can jump right into combat.  It's transport and trading capabilities are limited, so you'll have to really engage if you want pay off that debt.

It seems like these ships correspond to difficulty settings, easy, normal, or hard.  However, I didn't find much difference in difficulty between the cargo ship and the shuttle aside from the fact that the starter shuttle can jump between one more system than the cargo ship without needing to refuel. Payouts for transporting people seems to be a bit slim compared to payouts for massive hauling.  There is something in the game about illegal goods, but I have yet to discover them, or maybe I did and just haven't been discovered hauling them, yet.

Presuming you don't pick the fighter, the early game is about learning which systems need which goods and trading back and forth to rack up money so you can pay off that debt, and to acquire more ships.  One of the nice things is that you can acquire a second ship in your fleet rather early, with the debt still hanging over your head if you like, or just upgrade your ship to the next tier.  You'll need to hire extra crew to pilot extra ships, but that's far cheaper than the debt you are paying off.  Truth be told, the early game is really boring for a while.  It's just pick up a job/quest, buy some cargo, jump to the target system, sell cargo, repeat, with a lot of freedom in how you choose to make your money.  If you happen to run into some pirates, they'll likely destroy you, and you just reload and try again.

There is a story to follow, with only one campaign completed at this time, but progressing through the story is a bit random.  It requires you to land on certain planets in some sort of order, but I am not sure which planets or what order that is.  But hey, the game is open source.  If you want to see more depth, you are welcome to contribute to completing those other campaigns.
Another thing to do early on is explore all of the systems, so you can map out the galaxy and plan your routes easier, however many planets will sell you a local area map which eliminates some of that exploring for a fairly low price.

Though it bears no resemblance at all to FTL (no entering the ship and micromanaging crew details), I feel it would make for a decent roguelite and I have been playing it as such, deleting my profile every time I die.  Ironically, that is more enjoyable for me, in spite of the fact that the early game is so repetitive.  Not sure why.

All in all, if you don't mind unfinished projects, and like the idea of being an intergalactic merchant, there's very little reason to not give it a try.

So far its a very nice even if small game:

You start choosing naming your character, choosing your first ship wich will determine your role for quite some time (ship are expensive) and then pay off your debt of 450 000 credit, after this be free to choose your path

Be a bounty hunter, a merchant, a pirate, a commander of your own fleet, some event happens to pop up sometime so it doesn't feel like nothing happens in the game lore history

The game is good to chill out, gameplay is simple and it save every time you land on a planet, good for casual gamer or too kill some time

The AI is rather usefull, you will use them often until you buy (or manage to board) a bigger ship, random passing by ship can give you some fuel for 1 jump when there is no planet to land and refuel, they repair your ship so you can move again and even take on pirate on sight

reviewText:
Product received for free

Endless Sky is kinda like if EV Nova was a bit too fast paced, focused heavily on having a fleet rather than your warship doing the work, and loaded the pirates up with heavy weaponry on basically every pirate ship.

Otherwise it's very similar. Same grind to earn money/reputation, same obscure way to start plot(s), same tendency to sort of abruptly murder the player.

I'll be coming back to the game once the modders get their teeth into it, hopefully adding something like the railguns from EV Nova (my favorite weapon, sadly missing here). For now, I'd say wait til further in development.

reviewText: 
voteText: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The bottom line of this review is this: THIS GAME IS NOT EV NOVA. If you want to play EV Nova, GO PLAY EV NOVA - to this day, there is no suitable replacement for the original Escape Velocity games, and although Endless Sky comes close mechanically, it falls short atmospherically. The original EV games still hold up so if you are like me, with a hankering for that old EV feeling, you might as well just go play one of the originals.

[EDIT: I feel like I should just amend my review to say that Sunless Sea is a great modern game which is mechanically (if not thematically) similar to EV Nova and does a great job with atmosphere and writing, just with boats instead of space]

I was dying to play some EV Nova so I thought I'd try this game. It is a very accurate clone of many of the aspects of the Escape Velocity series, right down to the button labels and some ship designs, but somehow it doesn't all come together. Combat in Endless Sky isn't something you engage in, it's just something that seems to -happen- and then you either die or your enemies die. Every time I engaged in combat it felt totally binary, as if nothing i did tactically would alter my chances of win/loss. The game seriously needs to have its combat stats rebalanced to slow things down (esp. in the early game) and allow more drawn-out tactical encounters.

I did very much appreciate some of the improvements to the map/mission/trading interfaces, they make buy-low-sell-high a piece of cake with their profit/loss tracker. BUT, after several hours I actually found this detracted from one of the things I liked about Escape Velocity - the writing. It was so easy to fall into a trading groove that I actually found myself not even glancing at the planet and spaceport descriptions, and I found that after 12 hours I hadn't absorbed any of the flavor of the universe. Every planet became reduced to a set of pricing data. It just turns into a game of how-can-i-make-these-numbers-bigger.

My recommendation to other gamers is that instead of playing this game, you just find a copy of EV and play that. My recommendation to the developer of this game is to find a way to slow combat down and recapture the tension of EV (where did escape pods / hardmode go?).

reviewText:
it is free so cant complain i guess, seems like its not really finished. basically at teh begining you get to pick from 3 ships, if you dont pick the cargo ship you lose or you will be slow at making money you wont want to play.

pros:
its free and you might get a day worth of play out it

you can have a fleet of ships?

cons:
fighting is stupid, pretty much whoever has the better ships wins, which you might be thinking that makes sense, but there arent that many ships and you dont have many options on customizing your ship.

so lack of ships/items for ships. so you want a fast ship? well not really going to happen. you want a ship with lots of guns? well not really going to happen. best ship has 6 turrets and i think 2 maybe 4 guns, turrets auto aim, guns only fire frontwards, which combat isnt that well done so i usually took out he guns and added more shields. oh you want a ship with tons of shields? well doesnt seem to help much. if it was like skyranger and over time ships/ship items got better game would improve a bunch. not sure what i should do with 1000 million nothing to spend it on.

trade system is lacking, if you did trade runs you would never mke any money, have to do missions, which is fine  just random and boring after the 1000th time seeing your ship spin in circles over and over and over again.  looting pirates will make you more money than you ever dreamed of if you do it right and can get past the stupid fighting/controls.

looting ships or being a pirate is crap too, most of the time you try to disable a ship so you can loot it and the ai blows it, about 99.9% of the time. have to almost be alone against the other ship but then no point to a fleet, no hey fleet just disable them and go to next target so we can make money option!!!!! also not sure how you would be a pirate, ships move to fast to really target one thats not hostile, like the average merchant ship. plus one would think that you might find better systems on the pirate ships, since they do way better against you for what they have, but no. dont think i ever used any off of a ship except to sell.

story line. seen some reviews ssaying story line is awesome. from what i have seen you get special missions randomly from going to space ports. only problem is i have only seen 4 missions and dont think any of them are the main story line, and there is no telling where it begins. also ships randomly says stuff, like join the navy see the universe. havent been able to join any faction, or even see really any factions fighting besides pirates.

also the way ships move they have to come to complete stop the spin in a circle a couple of times before landing or hyperjumping. very annoying after a while.

but for a free game its worth every penny!!

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I first want to just say that I give the developer props for trying but unfortunately, the game just isn't for me. I don't understand the complaints about the visuals but I do unserstand the complaints about the controls. They're a little clunky and slow. I would generally be able to look over that if the game brought more to the table but unfortunately it just doesn't. My biggest issue is the cost of mortgage and rewards from missions. Rarely does the reward for the mission meet the cost of mortgage and leave enough left over to make decent money. Not only that, but the majority of missions are cargo based regardless of your ship type. As a fighter, I found that I often wouldn't have enough space whatsoever for many missions. That directly plays into the rewards. Granted, as was brought out to me, fighters are best for working at enemy ships. Overall, I have to say that this game isn't worth it for me, but, you may feel otherwise. Try it out.

reviewText:
This isn't so much a review, more so just making points of my experience with the gameplay so far.

My Experience with trading:

Trading isn't very complicated and let me get a feel for how ships fly

Pirates will spawn kill you along with spontainiously spawning ontop of you whenever they seemingly feel like it.

Majority of the enemies you run into will basically immediately kill you or disable you and from that point they will board you or someone else will come distract them to which point I've been unable to discover how to get my ship moving again as no one comes in range and I have to load or restart.

Enemies boarding seems majorly pointless anyway as it seems they just kill you off regardless and I have to load a save or restart.

Progression is painstakingly slow if you want to trade, slightly faster if you do missions but still very very slow.


My Experience with escourting:

Progress moves along much much faster than trading.

Near implausible to capture pirates as anyone you're escourting will just light up the already low health ship with turrets nearly immediately killing them

Getting spawnkilled and stomped on by literally everything still

At least I can run away faster than a cargo barge.

reviewText:
Beyond what is a very competent EV Nova clone, with trading, combat etc. I never felt like I was playing a game. You will be pressing two key an awful lot and these keys almost define the gameplay.

Lets say you are doing a trade run. You use the map to plot a course and leave the station. To get across space, on a journey of what could be many, many jumps you only need two keys!

J to jump
L to land

And that's it. You don't have to steer, you don't have to brake. When you press those keys the autopilot flies the ship for you. I never saw a lot of combat but was attacked on a couple of occasions by pirates. Fortunately my shields and armour held. But on those two occasions the only keys I pressed were J and L.

Oh, almost forgot. The game has almost no sound assets at all. No music and precious little effects. You can hear your thrusters and gunfire but the effects are entirely underwhelming.

reviewText:
I'm not going to go light on this game just because it's free. It's on Steam so it's  open to criticism.

Basically, this game suffers the same weaknesses as almost all other Github games. It was developed in an echochamber by entitled coder(s) with apparently little playtesting or outside player input, and the end result is a bunch of code that doesn't interact well. Lots of mechanics work against each other, and the game is barely playable as a result.

The problem with Github is that the average Github coder is a self-proclaimed creator who neither plays the game he helps create or listens to player input. The command structure is basic and not even the person who approves code merges bothers to playtest what he approves. As a result, Github games are always going to be barely playable messes. I liken Github to Communism: Wonderful in theory, completely dysfunctional and prone to failure in reality.

>all enemies will shoot the player craft into disabled mode, but not destroy purposefully
>pirates are completely ineffectual, random spawn mob enemies that die without accomplishment
>there is no difference between police and military, all government vessels are massive warships
>pirates only seek to disable other ships, nearly all other ships destroy pirates without attempting to loot
>the random ship spawn mechanic is not remotely balanced

Wouldn't play if it wasn't free, and it's unfinished Github fodder that doesn't belong on Steam.

reviewText:

WAY TOO TEDIOUS of a game.    If I ever have to play something this aggravating again without a GOOD & CLEAR tutorial I'd rather burn my computer then dismantle it.

reviewText:
Good thing: this game is AWESOME!!!

Bad thing: after just 18 hours of gaming i already got 6 Bactrian heavy warships so i dont really have a reason to keep playing this game... :/
(the Bactrian heavy warship is the biggest, baddest and heaviest ship in this whole game.)

This is an excellent game, probably the best free-to-play game on Steam. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a relaxing time shooting pirates and shipping cargo.\nPro-tip: pay off the mortgage ASAP, it's absolutely debilitating and you make a lot more money without it.

(WARNING: My comma key is broken expect run on sentences and lists without commas)
Endless Sky...
Long Version (Recommended to read)
Endless Sky is a 2D Space based action packed all in all fun game. At the start of the game you buy one out of 3 ships and then have to pay it off to make profit for another in the future. You can hunt pirates transport workers and tourists and transport cargo. I can't even explain the storyline..it's just..epic. It may not be multiplayer but the way this game is you'll rage quit after your ship blowing up for the 20th time.
Short Version
-Get Ship
-Raig at paying off loan
-Get tons of moolah
-Finish storyline
-Destroy everyone

Rating: 10/10
For a free game it's really fun. It's pretty easy to learn and there are a lot of helpful guides if you need some help. I rate it a perfect 5/7.

For a free game, this is a pretty interesting time killer. Once you get the hang of the basic controls, you can rack up money fairly quickly.

Tips
-Always buy the local map when you can, it will save you a lot of time.
-Start with the cargo ship, because transporting cargo is a steady way to make money. When you have some extra money, buy the cargo expansion and get an extra 15 slots for cargo, or chip away at the debt at the bank.
-A quick way to gain money is to find missions for cargo that are within 4-5 jumps. Take a look 1-2 jumps ahead to see what item will give you the most profit per unit, fill up on that, and go to that station, then repeat until you reach your destination.
-Cargo transports are like buying low and selling high, but you get the cargo for free, so the profit is WAY higher.

-How I started was with the cargo ship, and when I had about 500k extra, I bought another cargo ship like the one I started with. I got about 3-4 of them, then bought a small fighter to add to the group, they fight automatically.

-Open map with M, select a place to go to, but make sure ALL your ships have enough fuel to make it, you get refills by stopping at a planet.
-Use J to set all your ships to go to that place, they'll keep going until they get to the zone, but once you get there, make sure to hit L, or your ship will drift endlessly until you turn around to stop the momentum, or give it the land command with L.

Fun time killing game. Once I upgraded to bigger cargo ships that had blaster turrets, they were like self-defending cargo transports. I love it. With 5-6 of those things, little pirates fly by and get rekt.

This game is similar to most other top-down space trade sims I've played (like Escape Velocity Nova, VoidExpanse, etc.) with a few additional features like squad-like AI fleet (which is fun), and it's free!

It's worth noting, however, I'm about 30+ hours into the game and think I may have already broken the main quest.

Still, I'm give it a positive review because it's free and fun.

There is no excuse for not having this game. This is by far one of the best games I have ever played. Very well crafted engine, emmersive enviroments, great attention to detail, and finely tuned gameplay are just some of the joys you can expect while playing this game. I have played for several hours and have found not a single problem involving the writing. Everything about this game is great and it is sure to only get better. From hunting pirates, to epic full-scale galactic naval warfare, to rising from a lowly merchant scrounging by after buying his first starship, to controlling an intersteller mechant corperation, this game has it all. No matter how you want to play, you will have a good time.

As your ship enters an unexplored system you are greeted by a vastly superior pirate fleet, waiting in ambush.
You panic, your shields buying you precious seconds to choose an escape route.
With the last of your fuel you make a blind jump forward, hoping to land in friendly space.
You are dismayed as your ship enters an empty system, a dead end with pirates close behind you.
In panic, you scan for a planet you can land on, hoping to hide from the pirates.
Your ship veers to the side as it detects a large anomoly, its only identification as ????"
The Pirates

Not terribly complex or deep, but in terms of 2d space trade/shoot/whatever-em-ups that're out there, it's very clean and enjoyable. Being free is a big bonus as well.

I've had hours of fun playing this game, and I'm still nowhere near the endgame.  Generic missions supply most of the gameplay, with a huge main story (possibly multiple?) which gives access to new technologies and changes the universe.\nExtendable using plugins, and in open source development... What's not to love!

The game as it stands is very, very young, meaning that more people and time are needed to help build this community built game, but that is the only negative.

All the great and positive aspects about the game:

Single Ship + Multi-ship customization
Great Free Worlds Campaign (rest isn't finished)
Sandbox (even though it pushes you to become a pirater of pirates)
Very Simple Controls
Not CPU/GPU intensive (except in epic battles)
Moddable with all coding available at your fingertips
Plenty of Challenges like Nuke Doging, Worldship Capturing, and my favorite, Epic batte Scenes with 100+ ships engaged in combat = complete and utter lag of goodness as I watch my enemy's ships turn to space dust

To summarize, this game is constanly developing, and is worth the $5 you will never have to pay for it because it is being built by the community, making it even greater.

Whenever I look for a space ship sim I almost exclusively judge it on whether or not I can get every ship in the game. Whether or not I can buy the stupidly monstrous carrier or capital ship is always a good indicator of whether or not the developers love themselves, and apparently these guys do.

The art design is STELLARPUN and the UI is very clean and relatively easy to read. The lore background given for each and every planet is intricately detailed, which I am genuinely surprised to see, and reflects the developers' dedication to this game. The gameplay is relatively simple, incredibly simple if you plan on only trading, but you can make it as challenging as you want, which is a rare feature to offer that isn't a difficulty slider in the settings menu. This, paired with the branching dialogue options make this game a very solid space rpg.

tl;dr I would pay money for this game, the quality is so good.Also because capital ships.

If I were to nitpick at this good FREE game, I would say that travelling in general is too hands-off and could get boring after a period of time, but aside from that, this game is a diamond in the rough. I hope to see more from these guys!

An unbelievably simple and stunning game. Fun to play, hours of progression and so on. The ship choices are neat and all the little hidden things are fabulous. Additionally the map system is extensive and each planet has individual stats which follow a pattern. Me likes, 10/10 .

Endless Sky is a game that anyone can play and enjoy. The game has a steep learning curve, but once you've mastered it the potential that you have is limitless. You can be a heavily armed merchant who does a varity of jobs, you can assemble a fleet of warships and become the most dangerous pirate in the universe with endless riches, or you can make a space taxi business ... the choices are endless in Endless Sky. You just have to make the right ones.
Very addicting is all I'm going to say.

Let me praise this game for doing some things well; Trading is fun, making money feels fun, story is better than expected, and playing the game as a merchant/bounty hunter is really fun. Most of the game feels fun, but it lacks in some departments. Firefights? They feel...meh. Keep back and shoot missiles or get in their face with a huge ship and turrets. I don't know what else to say besides it feels pretty meh. Next, where is the story? Everynow and then, I'll encounter a mission, but then, nothing. Days, weeks, months go by, and there's no story missions to be found. Without them, the grind goes on and on and it feels like all my progress has been for nothing. Story missions should be closer together and easier to find and do, otherwise it leaves the player without a sense of purpose, which leads to, why am I even playing this?" Also

reviewText: This game is an excellent idea. However, right now it really lacks the polish that would make it fun. For instance, there's a reason Escape Velocity prevented you from making a hyperspace jump too close to the center of a system: without it this restriction, traffic moves too fast, and systems lack a sense of structure and atmosphere. Heck, even the asteroids move too fast. Combat is ridiculously fast, too. I can't learn anything from it, or even have fun running away from a much more powerful enemy and getting killed anyway—you just get zapped and die.\n\nI don't regret giving this a shot, and I think it has potential, but I don't recommend it right now. Modders will probably love it, though.

It looked pretty cool, but it frequently dropped to 1 FPS and I could hardly do anything. I don't know if it's something with my computer or with the game itself, but if you want to play it, go ahead. I was fairly disappointed by the poor performance of such a small game that should really be able to run flawlessly on just about anything.
A fantastic Game, really clever adding in the banking/loan side of things. Look forward to future updates.

This game reminds me a lot of an older game I played in high school called EV Nova. Similar play style, although slightly fewer 'events' and more limited ship choice. The combat is my only gripe at the moment, with anything but turrets being far too hard to control. Also trading is OP as ♥♥♥♥, but overall, a really fun game.

A very faithful successor to the EV Nova series. Upon finding this game, I was more excited about playing it than any other game in recent memory, and it lived up to my expectations. That's not to say it has no creativity though. The developer did some things that I thought were really cool (like added a way to find weapons and ships from the map), and some things that I personally wouldn't have done (took out specialty commodities, likely because these are also visible from the map), but overall is a fantastic package. The string I played even has a solid story that is up to the high standard set by the EV games. Would highly recommend, and the fact that it's free makes it a no-brainer. I wish I could donate.\n\nIn the instance that this is read by a creator, I'd say it would be cool to consider adding specialty commodities back in, but excluding them from the map interface. Just a thought. Other than that thanks so much for doing what I wish I could have done myself, and make the EV series live on.

This game is very well made, but the gameplay can be difficult, and the tutorials are a little confusing. Overall, I recomend this game to any person interested in space age rpg's. The story is well written from what I have managed to see so far, I would rate this a solid 7/10.

if you like Escape velocity, this is basically it. im pretty thrilled about it. i hated that EV games just kind of lingered and disappeared. this is the same idea, but it looks nicer, and it has gameplay improvements over EV Nova. jumps don't require moving away from planets as that is just a time hog, and auto pilots will assist your landing to make things less frustrating. the map could be bigger, and as mods are made for it, im sure it will become the community game it should be. i think you are gonna love it, and you can't beat free. you don't like their free game? thats your fault not theirs. they give and you just take, like a filthy horse person. just give it a try. you'll see its as good as you could possibly hope for, and likely to get better once the community gets its hands on it. hell i already made my own mod with 2 new planets, it took me like 30 minutes. more dedicated people will likely whip up a full star wars mod in like 2 weeks, by just converting the images and scripts from the EV mods.

I keep battling with myself on whether this game is good or not. It's certainly got a little effort put into it - and it's free to boot. But on the flip side it's not a game anyone would have paid to play.

It's certainly addicting and plays heavy on the psychological urge to make the numbers grow - I played 8 hours of this yet I feel like I just started the game - but there's nothing I can honestly point out and say that was fun" about those 8 hours spent. Just a compelling urge to get back to it to make money and get better ships.

The combat is over nearly the instant it begins. If you get attacked the game is already decided as there's no actual time to think or react; before you can even visually see an enemy you often get shot from offscreen by a torpedo or rapidly hit by a fighter's beams in a way that just kills you inside 2-4 seconds of popping into the system. If you buy escort ships they can defend you
date: but the combat is over too fast for you (the human-controlled ship) to actually participate in any meaningful way.\n\nThere are quests that spice the game up a little bit with story if you stop off in some spaceports. They're not terribly different than other jobs you can get in actual function
recommended:
but you get a little story to go with the game.

The greater part of this game is just grabbing junk from one place and selling it in another place. Pirates show up at times and typically - if you're alone - they kill you before you can do anything about it.The game isn't brutal though. It autosaves everytime you land on a planet so if you die it's barely an inconvienence.

It's a free game so you can't really go wrong giving it a shot."

Possibly the best free game I've played in quite a while. You can choose to go with a lot of different playstyles, either sticking to strictly legitimate (a long slow grind involving raising your in-game credit score ... no seriously), OOOOOR ... blow up pirates and run drugs through high security space.

I mean, the choice is obvious.

The map is pretty expansive. Not limitless, but large enough that getting from one end to the other will take a while, and probably end up being very expensive depending on how many ships and crew you have.

Definitely a game you can lose several hours in.

Endless Sky is a refreshing, fantastic little space trading and exploration game, which rises above the other absolute drivel of Steam's Free-To-Play tab. The entire game is lovingly crafted, and completely, utterly, no-strings-attached, free. Which amazes me, as in this modern world of gaming dominated by big-name companies flaunting their obvious monopoly over most of the electronic entertainment business, Endless Sky proves that you can make an entirely free game that isn't cynically devoid of all actual gameplay. And, as I browse through the reviews, it's easy to see that the only negative reviewers haven't taken the time to enjoy this game in all of its fully realized glory. Of course, Endless Sky is still in development, with only part of the actual story mission done, but the story it does offer at this moment is top of the notch. The characters are engaging, and the missions that connect each new quest  are simple, but challenging. And hey, as everyone else seems to enjoy saying, it's free. Why not try it?

As your ship enters an unexplored system you are greeted by a vastly superior pirate fleet, waiting in ambush.
You panic, your shields buying you precious seconds to choose an escape route.
With the last of your fuel you make a blind jump forward, hoping to land in friendly space.
You are dismayed as your ship enters an empty system, a dead end with pirates close behind you.
In panic, you scan for a planet you can land on, hoping to hide from the pirates.
Your ship veers to the side as it detects a large anomoly, its only identification as ????"
The Pirates

reviewText: There is no excuse for not having this game. This is by far one of the best games I have ever played. Very well crafted engine, emmersive enviroments, great attention to detail, and finely tuned gameplay are just some of the joys you can expect while playing this game. I have played for several hours and have found not a single problem involving the writing. Everything about this game is great and it is sure to only get better. From hunting pirates, to epic full-scale galactic naval warfare, to rising from a lowly merchant scrounging by after buying his first starship, to controlling an intersteller mechant corperation, this game has it all. No matter how you want to play, you will have a good time.

reviewText: This game is an excellent idea. However, right now it really lacks the polish that would make it fun. For instance, there's a reason Escape Velocity prevented you from making a hyperspace jump too close to the center of a system: without it this restriction, traffic moves too fast, and systems lack a sense of structure and atmosphere. Heck, even the asteroids move too fast. Combat is ridiculously fast, too. I can't learn anything from it, or even have fun running away from a much more powerful enemy and getting killed anyway—you just get zapped and die.\n\nI don't regret giving this a shot, and I think it has potential, but I don't recommend it right now. Modders will probably love it, though.

For a free game, this is a pretty interesting time killer. Once you get the hang of the basic controls, you can rack up money fairly quickly.

Tips
-Always buy the local map when you can, it will save you a lot of time.
-Start with the cargo ship, because transporting cargo is a steady way to make money. When you have some extra money, buy the cargo expansion and get an extra 15 slots for cargo, or chip away at the debt at the bank.
-A quick way to gain money is to find missions for cargo that are within 4-5 jumps. Take a look 1-2 jumps ahead to see what item will give you the most profit per unit, fill up on that, and go to that station, then repeat until you reach your destination.
-Cargo transports are like buying low and selling high, but you get the cargo for free, so the profit is WAY higher.

-How I started was with the cargo ship, and when I had about 500k extra, I bought another cargo ship like the one I started with. I got about 3-4 of them, then bought a small fighter to add to the group, they fight automatically.

-Open map with M, select a place to go to, but make sure ALL your ships have enough fuel to make it, you get refills by stopping at a planet.
-Use J to set all your ships to go to that place, they'll keep going until they get to the zone, but once you get there, make sure to hit L, or your ship will drift endlessly until you turn around to stop the momentum, or give it the land command with L.

reviewText: I feel like I've only scratched the surface of this game. It's immersive, and the writing is well done. Combat is eh

I got this game thinking, you know I am bored.  None of my games have been up to par to what I want to play.  Honestly I am glad I did.  It may be a casual game, however, it has some nice graphics for a 2D game.  I started playing it, and the only things I have found to be flaws are as follows:

1) The 'main' plotline can be a bit hard to find if you don't always check the spaceports.  Even then, those space ports can be very hard to find due to the vastness of the star system of the game.  Just a minor drawback, still it has a very catchy story so far what I have seen.  I won't spoil it too much but you can side with at least two factions from what I have seen.  THere are at least 5 factions I have found.  Including one that eluded me for the longest time actually.

2) Controls could be a bit more universal and the starter ship is a bit hard to control.  However that starter ship will do mostly running away till you can afford a new ship.(which can take a while to do)  Just remember, don't go into 'dead space' with only 1-2 bars of fuel.  Unless you know there is an inhabited spot in distance to get too.  You can refill from allied ships but due to me just testing mechanics and what not, I did get stuck ina  spot where only pirates were and they wouldn't help even after paying a bribe.

3) Found a bug that if you actualy ahve a fleet of ships and you jump before they leave the planet and join you.  They will actualy be stuck in an endless loop going in and out of the planet.  However if you multi jump with all ships in space, they will actualy stop for refuels if they don't have the same amount of fuel.

4) The economy.  I don't know if this gets better in time, but due to the storyline I would say it would for someone of your stature(Unless the faction you chose can be a money grubbing -Insert favorite derogatory here-)  You start off paying off 450k of a loan with 0.400% intrest and it is near impossible to pay on time every time.  SO it takes a while to get rid of that first ship.  After that however, money is rather easy if you play it JUSSST right.  So a slight more ballancing will be needed on that.

All in all however, this game is a must have.  It may be casual, but if you go hardcore on it, oh my does it get quite interesting.

I'm a huge fan of EV. This does several things better than EV, and there are things that EV does much better.

ES's strengths:
I really like the finance system in ES much more than just simple credits. I personally wish that the loan system was more complex than it is currently, but I know that this wouldn't be as accessible for everybody. I was very delighted to see how the finances worked.
I also really like how the trade system works. Every planet has a Trade Center
date:
which isn't available in EV. This allows a TON of flexibility when it comes to trade routes. This functionality works great in conjunction with the features of the Map.
The Map has MUCH more features than EV's. For one, in addition to the great trade options listed above, the map will display prices for each commodity in each system, and compare it with the prices of your current system! This is an AMAZING feature!!!! It also color-codes each system in regards to the actual prices of each commodity. This will let you supercharge trade routes with only a few clicks. It also lets you search for planets and systems that sell specific outfits and ships. Want a Laser Turret? Find a system that's guaranteed to sell Laser Turrets easily!
And, it's free.

EV's Strengths:
Most noticibly, EV's presentation and gameplay are smoother, especially when talking about EV Nova. The art and assets really stand out. Details within the ships' and planets' design give the world a ton of personality that you can really feel. The quick, tight controls of the fighters and the sluggish, aching turn of the heavy freighters are felt as much as seen. Each world has much more personality and diversity than ES's worlds. The planets aren't just described through the text, but their consistency is maintained through the art on the planet and the profile of the world from space. It's all consistent, and that makes you feel like you're actually traveling the stars. It's something Ambrosia is really good at creating. EV also has several government types, each with their own quirks. The political territories feel completely different from one another. Being in Federal space is obvious, and being in Rebel space is obvious. In any EV game, you can immediately tell which faction's space you're in instantaniously.
EV is definitely a more hands-on game, which I perfer. ES is basically an autopilot flier. You can take manual control if you'd like - such as for combat purposes - but you don't need to. EV's controls require you to stay engaged with the world, and therein makes you immersed in the story. If I'm doing cargo runs in ES, I can set up my route, hit J" and walk away for a full minute while I wait for the series of jumps to complete. That wait time breaks the immersion of the game. And speaking of story
recommended: EV Nova actually has stories; several stories are strung throughout the galaxy - each one unique. You can travel through these stories to pick up a ton of great gear

A 'practically endless' sci-fi -inspired sandbox with a distinctively classical gameplay... It kinda saddens me that this kind of game concepts are pretty much ignored by the AAA studios and publishers, because I'd love to see a game where I could do all of this in first person. (Star Citizen, maybe?)
Teh arbitrary list of pros and cons goes here:

Pros:
- An original sci-fi world with its own lore, locales, races, thingmagajigs etc. Lots of descriptions, random events and tiny detail you could admire for hours and hours...

- The game leaves the exploration and discovery to you and there's direct benefits as well as risks to it. I know its hard to achieve with the level of writing shown here, but I kinda wish there was a random map generator and/or more rogue-like elements for additional replay value.

-The learning/grinding curve feels rough and tedious at times, but it's never unfair other than in the way you'd expect it
to be. (You're a lone, debt-ridden pilot in space, anyone could be your enemy if you decide to make them one...)

-You can be a transporter or a merchant and moreover, it's profitable and compelling enough on its own, you never feel like the story or the gameplay is forcing any of the combat and conflict on you. (This is what practically every other sci-fi -themed, or rather, every other videogame is guilty of...)

-It's not like they forgot about conflict either, sure you can become a space pirate or a bounty hunter, even a scout if you will, but it's way more risky than being a merchant, and rightly so.

Cons:
- Combat is clunky, you feel like inertia is your main enemy, as you and your opponent spin around in awkward circles  briefly barraging each other with your weapons before flying off in separate directions... (Most of of the time is easier to avoid fighting all together, and true enough, transporters and freighters are not even designed for combat, but having it in there, I'd love if it was a bit more accessible to a new player, since I don't feel any sort of motivation to try and learn about combat in its current form.)

- Everything is ready for you.." This is kind of hard to pin down and sure
date: a lot of it is convenient and makes sense from the 'viewpoint of a game' but it's still kind of iffy how you never have trouble finding wares to sell off in other systems
hoursPlayed: paying passengers that won't mind even if you take a detour here or there

reviewText: Great and intereseting(?)  game, lots of options!\n\nI love how it is open source so you can change lots of things and then mess up then try it again, and since i'm a computer studies student it is interseting learning about other coding laungeges and the simularities.

Do you know the kind of games where you farm resource routes to make virtual money in a very complex economy system?! And evolve with the profits you generate?!
Welcome to Endless Sky!

Honestly, the graphics (and the looong list of commands) kept me away from the game for a while. It is only after I noticed we could barely use 3 keys (J, L, M by default) and have an unexplicable amount of fun during this game.

The gameplay is very simple, but I honestly can't recommend this game enough. It's a very thrilling experience between travelling space, recruiting ships/crew, accomplishing missions, fighting/fleeing pirates, joining a clan...

What I didn't like:
- The other ships in the game are extremely random. Some planets are very calm, and one second after, they become raging with pirates and Republican resistance... Instant kills are in order!
- No real story, really. The first missions show you how to navigate and play (some sort of tutorial) and then, nothing else. Just a bunch of exploding ships...
- The ships you buy are default. No customization possible on their skins (though you can buy wepaons and stuff on them, still not accurate though since that takes up place from the merchandise too)

What kept me playing for hours now:
- Money! Money! MONEY! It's what keeps you farming circuits for hours!
- 3 keys to manage it all; some sort of pre-built autopilot for your ship.
- Reading about the planets and discovering new horizons. Each system has a planet or more with different stories. It's just amazing how much work was put in that!
- The map is EXTREMELY, I say EXTREMELY WELL OPTIMIZED!! If you get to know it, everything is shown from missions, nearby planets with their economy, destination, where you should and should not go! It's the MOST amazing map in a ES clone-game I've ever seen!
- Have a fleet, conquer space! Satisfy your ego!
- Free open-source game! It will surely improve fast!

Excellent game, that will surely improve in the upcoming months!! ;)

reviewText:
Excellent! Feels just like EV all over again. I haven't gotten super deep into it, but I'm impressed with the writing and areas where it polishes some of the rough edges from EV.

It still has some issues, like the fact that it can take too long to jump between systems (lots of repetitive jumping can end up happening), and the ships look very samey and unexciting.

I love this game!

In short, if liked the original Escape Velocity, you will probably enjoy Endless Sky. The gameplay is a near carbon copy, with a handful of small refinements, and strong writing. If you never played EV, this game may seem a little dated at first, and the learning curve may be a bit steep, but there is a lot to love here even if it does feel a bit incomplete right now (version 0.8.4).

Pros:
- It's Escape Velocity!
- Writing is really very good.
- Space and planets are quite pretty.

Cons:
- Content needs more fleshing out, particularly outfits and missions.
- Gameplay is occasionally too streamlined, simplifying things like trading to the point where a lot of the fun is lost.
- Ships and combat are fairly ugly, especially when compared to EV Nova.
- I'd love to see a little more innovation on the original EV model.

reviewText: Okay where do i begin well I'll start by describing it. This game is a 2D sci-fi game where you start off buying your first ship (after taking a sizeable loan just over 420k) you meet people in spaceports that give you quests you can choose your career of a trader,cruise ship captain,bounty hunter, freedom fighter, pirate, the list goes on. It's really dependant on your style of play. I opted to be a frieghter captain contracting my services for stable income and occasionally disabling small pirate craft and taking all their equipment. After awhile you pay off your loan and really your story depends on where you head off too. Shortly after my first mission I took a contract that took my south of the starting area and as i delivered my cargo i checked the spaceport and ended up being recruited by some of the free fighters to observe some systems. I further assisted them recieving a nice profit for good work nothing too bad just a smuggling of a person here and there. Overall the missions you get are well written in my opinion as well as some of your responces (I did the karate move for kicks fyi). The ship and module variaty seemed quite low at first untill i realized duh your not gonna have a planet selling every ship variaty. I started exploring and bam many new ships and modules were discovered. However the UI for the modules could use a little more clarity ( thought i might sell my ship by selling a module at first) but after about 15-30 minutes you get the hang of it. So for a free game 10/10 there is no downside to downloading this game since it's so small. If i had to pay for this game i might pause since the combat seems a little harsh some times (but hey i was a freighter not a fighter so i cant judge to harshly) still if they asked under 5$ it would still be reasonable the universe is quiet well crafted. Why are you still reading this hit the download button and play it now! STOP READING AND PLAY NOW!!!

I'm not eloquent enough to make a review that truly captures the essence of Endless Sky, so I won't try. I will however say that, while some bits are still being worked on (only one storyline is available so far), it is completely free (read that again: FREE), has a small but growing modding community (lore-accurate Star Wars mods anyone?), is very easy to play (becomes second nature after a short time), and has great writing.

TL:DR
Keep on Space Truckin'

This game is really fantastic. Everything, the mechanics, the gameplay, even the graphics are great (for what it is). reviewText: Liked the game from start to finish. No bugs to report. Some minor missing art here and there in the shopping screen but all in all a very good game. After playing through the masterfully written quest line (with player choices & a very big and noticeable impact on the universe!) the game feels a bit empty due to there being no real way to conquer the universe besides making planets pay a daily fee after destroying their fleet. And no way to spend the ridiculous amount of money you can make. As soon as you are rich getting a lot richer is a piece of cake. But definitely a solid 30-50 hours of very enjoyable gameplay. Can't wait for the other 2 quest lines & maybe a way to have a more personal control on planets or the universe.

I had a three-ship fleet including a hauler 3 with level 2 atom thrusters and level 3 atom steering and level 4 shields, a berserker with the same engines and shields and a hauler 1 that i had transferred into a light warship by sacrificing all my cargo space for outfits, installed top level shields , three heavy laser turrets and level 4 atom engines. Both haulers also had fission reacyor+ lvl 4 battery and all the ships had cooling ducts. The total fleet was worth something between 20 and 30 million, and i also had 15 million obtained mainly by selling outfits stolen from pirate ships. So total i had 35-45 million. And guess what? I accidentally loaded an autosave this had done in the beginning of my career, where i even hadn't paid the starting loan back. So his game deleted the newer save and replaced it with this beginning save, making me to start over.\n\nOtherwise it's a good game. It would also be nice if someone knew if i can get the saving back...

When i first saw this, and read the description, I didn't completely expect what I got. There isn't as much of that exploration-feeling as I thought there would be, as most systems are inhabited. Those which aren't are therefore violent traps you will most probably die within in the first minute. At least with the beginning ship. But even inhabited and highly guarded systems are (in seldom cases) attacked by pirates or other enemies, which makes you to never feel completely safe...

Pros:
- Neat graphics
- no bugs or glitches
- no lags, even at highest settings
- editors for map and ships (which means, you can edit everything)
- interesting upgrades system, using several kinds of slots
- customizing your ship is very easy
- tutorial mission showing you everything, even how deadly space can be...
- the story can be ignored by the player, or changed, but events always take effect on you
- several possibilities for better engines/weapons/other components
- galaxywide market system incorporating your buying/selling decisions into the prices

Cons
- no multiplayer ( which isn't really needed, I just wanted to have something on contra side :D )

Conclusion:
An awesome space game, completely free of bugs and lags, just as you would want a new game to be :)

Update 11/8: Still no bugs, I have already played around with plugins a little. That's also the way I obtained a fleet of several alien spaceships, even some Quarg ships.

Poitives:
+Free
+Will run extremely well on a toaster.
+Expansive universe with a lot of detail for each world.
+Well written and thought out descriptions for everything planet, ship, and object in the game.
+Interesting quests that you will come naturally if you always check out the space ports.
+Simply but (mostly) relaxing trading mechanics.
+EXTREMELY immersive dispite it's simplicity.

Negatives
-No music, although you can easily fix that by setting your own music (say the soundtrack FTL) in the background.
-The game is bad at explaining things. There is a fine difference between having your hand held as your lead down a completely linear experience (ala Call of Duty) and not actually telling the player how to use even basic controls. For example, the game told how to open up your star map by hitting M to select a star system and that you jump to that system by hittingJ. What the game didn't tell me was that you had to actually EXIT your star map, THEN hit J to jump to the system.
As I said, you will randomly (and rarely) find quests if you visit the space port in each system, but nothing in the game even alludes to this fact, I found that out by accident. Also, you have to hold the space bar to quick buy a large amount of things in the trading area, which again I learned by accident (before that I was clicking for each and every piece of metal I was buying up).
-Combat is random, not all that interesting, and is always one sided one way or another. Pirates will randomly appear in a sector. If your a fighter, you turn your ship and fire your weapons at the enemy and hope they die before you do. If you are in a freighter, your guns turn so you don't have to (although freighters really suck at turning anyway) and again, you have to hope they die before you do. Either a single pirate ship will jump into a system teaming with a dozen friendly ships and die immediately, or six pirates will jump on you as your leaving a planet and blast you to bits without you being able to do anything. Death just makes you reload back to whatever planet you were last landed on, but that only highlights what a nusance combat in this game is.

Still, on the whole the game is one of the most immersive games I have played in years, and it is VERY easy to lose an embaressingly large amount of time to this game.

A worthy successor to the Escape Velocity series.  Quite a few of the annoyances of the franchise have been skillfully addressed here and it makes Endless Sky much more than just a trip through the past.

I was a huge fan of Escape Velocity in the old days, and this feels like the sequel to Nova I always wanted.  Still a little short in the story department, this game has a solid foundation and a LOT of room to grow.

A lot of fun. Enjoying it more than some paid titles.

Love the customizability too - want to throw your shield generator out the airlock to make space for a cargo expansion module? It lets you do that. (or you can just use the default if you can't be bothered to tweak)

Open source, cross platform, which is a big win too!

A 'practically endless' sci-fi -inspired sandbox with a distinctively classical gameplay... It kinda saddens me that this kind of game concepts are pretty much ignored by the AAA studios and publishers, because I'd love to see a game where I could do all of this in first person. (Star Citizen, maybe?)
Teh arbitrary list of pros and cons goes here:

Pros:
- An original sci-fi world with its own lore, locales, races, thingmagajigs etc. Lots of descriptions, random events and tiny detail you could admire for hours and hours...

- The game leaves the exploration and discovery to you and there's direct benefits as well as risks to it. I know its hard to achieve with the level of writing shown here, but I kinda wish there was a random map generator and/or more rogue-like elements for additional replay value.

-The learning/grinding curve feels rough and tedious at times, but it's never unfair other than in the way you'd expect it
to be. (You're a lone, debt-ridden pilot in space, anyone could be your enemy if you decide to make them one...)

-You can be a transporter or a merchant and moreover, it's profitable and compelling enough on its own, you never feel like the story or the gameplay is forcing any of the combat and conflict on you. (This is what practically every other sci-fi -themed, or rather, every other videogame is guilty of...)

-It's not like they forgot about conflict either, sure you can become a space pirate or a bounty hunter, even a scout if you will, but it's way more risky than being a merchant, and rightly so.

Cons:
- Combat is clunky, you feel like inertia is your main enemy, as you and your opponent spin around in awkward circles  briefly barraging each other with your weapons before flying off in separate directions... (Most of of the time is easier to avoid fighting all together, and true enough, transporters and freighters are not even designed for combat, but having it in there, I'd love if it was a bit more accessible to a new player, since I don't feel any sort of motivation to try and learn about combat in its current form.)

- Everything is ready for you.." This is kind of hard to pin down and sure
date: a lot of it is convenient and makes sense from the 'viewpoint of a game' but it's still kind of iffy how you never have trouble finding wares to sell off in other systems
hoursPlayed: paying passengers that won't mind even if you take a detour here or there
voteText: missions for a lone hauler with no-one to protect their freight and so on. (I'd say there's lots of room for additional writing and game design here

reviewText: I just fell in love with this game. I have played the X-Games for years and even if this one is a simple 2D space adventure the complexity is insane. Trading, pirating, exploring, upgrading. Everything that made the X-Games fun you will find in Endless Sky.
Charming little 2D Elite type of thing.
Amazing game with a wide variety of ships and the chance to create your own story.\ncustomize your ship to your needs, steal other ships or become one of the galaxy's biggest traders.

I got this game thinking, you know I am bored.  None of my games have been up to par to what I want to play.  Honestly I am glad I did.  It may be a casual game, however, it has some nice graphics for a 2D game.  I started playing it, and the only things I have found to be flaws are as follows:

1) The 'main' plotline can be a bit hard to find if you don't always check the spaceports.  Even then, those space ports can be very hard to find due to the vastness of the star system of the game.  Just a minor drawback, still it has a very catchy story so far what I have seen.  I won't spoil it too much but you can side with at least two factions from what I have seen.  THere are at least 5 factions I have found.  Including one that eluded me for the longest time actually.

2) Controls could be a bit more universal and the starter ship is a bit hard to control.  However that starter ship will do mostly running away till you can afford a new ship.(which can take a while to do)  Just remember, don't go into 'dead space' with only 1-2 bars of fuel.  Unless you know there is an inhabited spot in distance to get too.  You can refill from allied ships but due to me just testing mechanics and what not, I did get stuck ina  spot where only pirates were and they wouldn't help even after paying a bribe.

3) Found a bug that if you actualy ahve a fleet of ships and you jump before they leave the planet and join you.  They will actualy be stuck in an endless loop going in and out of the planet.  However if you multi jump with all ships in space, they will actualy stop for refuels if they don't have the same amount of fuel.

4) The economy.  I don't know if this gets better in time, but due to the storyline I would say it would for someone of your stature(Unless the faction you chose can be a money grubbing -Insert favorite derogatory here-)  You start off paying off 450k of a loan with 0.400% intrest and it is near impossible to pay on time every time.  SO it takes a while to get rid of that first ship.  After that however, money is rather easy if you play it JUSSST right.  So a slight more ballancing will be needed on that.

All in all however, this game is a must have.  It may be casual, but if you go hardcore on it, oh my does it get quite interesting.

I'm a huge fan of EV. This does several things better than EV, and there are things that EV does much better.

ES's strengths:
I really like the finance system in ES much more than just simple credits. I personally wish that the loan system was more complex than it is currently, but I know that this wouldn't be as accessible for everybody. I was very delighted to see how the finances worked.
I also really like how the trade system works. Every planet has a Trade Center
date:
which isn't available in EV. This allows a TON of flexibility when it comes to trade routes. This functionality works great in conjunction with the features of the Map.
The Map has MUCH more features than EV's. For one, in addition to the great trade options listed above, the map will display prices for each commodity in each system, and compare it with the prices of your current system! This is an AMAZING feature!!!! It also color-codes each system in regards to the actual prices of each commodity. This will let you supercharge trade routes with only a few clicks. It also lets you search for planets and systems that sell specific outfits and ships. Want a Laser Turret? Find a system that's guaranteed to sell Laser Turrets easily!
And, it's free.

EV's Strengths:
Most noticibly, EV's presentation and gameplay are smoother, especially when talking about EV Nova. The art and assets really stand out. Details within the ships' and planets' design give the world a ton of personality that you can really feel. The quick, tight controls of the fighters and the sluggish, aching turn of the heavy freighters are felt as much as seen. Each world has much more personality and diversity than ES's worlds. The planets aren't just described through the text, but their consistency is maintained through the art on the planet and the profile of the world from space. It's all consistent, and that makes you feel like you're actually traveling the stars. It's something Ambrosia is really good at creating. EV also has several government types, each with their own quirks. The political territories feel completely different from one another. Being in Federal space is obvious, and being in Rebel space is obvious. In any EV game, you can immediately tell which faction's space you're in instantaniously.
EV is definitely a more hands-on game, which I perfer. ES is basically an autopilot flier. You can take manual control if you'd like - such as for combat purposes - but you don't need to. EV's controls require you to stay engaged with the world, and therein makes you immersed in the story. If I'm doing cargo runs in ES, I can set up my route, hit J" and walk away for a full minute while I wait for the series of jumps to complete. That wait time breaks the immersion of the game. And speaking of story
recommended: EV Nova actually has stories; several stories are strung throughout the galaxy - each one unique. You can travel through these stories to pick up a ton of great gear

Also, as it can be a struggle at times, but I like that. But just as things seem bad, I started getting bounty hunter missions. So my weird custom city-ship is finally seeing some real combat. And, if you need money, try disabling larger pirate ships and steal all their best outfits and cargo.

The only control missing, unless I haven't found it yet is EV's old auto pilot for combat.
