The Game is fun. Decent Graphics, Simple Controls, Great mechanics, and a not-too-shabby 'tutorial'.
There are a few drawbacks, though. Replayability is a bit on the low side, as progression is a bit slow and you end up doing very similar missions over and over until you have a ship capable of actually fighting Pirates, which can take a while to get.
There is an occaisional bug here and there, but other than that the game runs smoothly.

Aside from the progression issues, I see potential in this game. I love how you can run out of fuel in an uninhabited sector and have to call a nearby merchant for help. I like the money system, how you can ferry goods from one place to another to earn a profit. I like how the gameplay feels, and I would love to see a Multiplayer function.

Overall, great game. Definitely worth the money... oh wait, this game is free. also a plus.

A 'practically endless' sci-fi -inspired sandbox with a distinctively classical gameplay... It kinda saddens me that this kind of game concepts are pretty much ignored by the AAA studios and publishers, because I'd love to see a game where I could do all of this in first person. (Star Citizen, maybe?)
Teh arbitrary list of pros and cons goes here:

Pros:
- An original sci-fi world with its own lore, locales, races, thingmagajigs etc. Lots of descriptions, random events and tiny detail you could admire for hours and hours...

- The game leaves the exploration and discovery to you and there's direct benefits as well as risks to it. I know its hard to achieve with the level of writing shown here, but I kinda wish there was a random map generator and/or more rogue-like elements for additional replay value.

-The learning/grinding curve feels rough and tedious at times, but it's never unfair other than in the way you'd expect it
to be. (You're a lone, debt-ridden pilot in space, anyone could be your enemy if you decide to make them one...)

-You can be a transporter or a merchant and moreover, it's profitable and compelling enough on its own, you never feel like the story or the gameplay is forcing any of the combat and conflict on you. (This is what practically every other sci-fi -themed, or rather, every other videogame is guilty of...)

-It's not like they forgot about conflict either, sure you can become a space pirate or a bounty hunter, even a scout if you will, but it's way more risky than being a merchant, and rightly so.

Cons:
- Combat is clunky, you feel like inertia is your main enemy, as you and your opponent spin around in awkward circles  briefly barraging each other with your weapons before flying off in separate directions... (Most of of the time is easier to avoid fighting all together, and true enough, transporters and freighters are not even designed for combat, but having it in there, I'd love if it was a bit more accessible to a new player, since I don't feel any sort of motivation to try and learn about combat in its current form.)

- Everything is ready for you.." This is kind of hard to pin down and sure

This game is free. This game does not seem like a free game now that I've played a bit. I would totally spend money on it. BUT I DON'T HAVE TO! The fact that this is only a beta version just makes me even more excited for what's to come.

Not to mention, the game is Open Source and allows for anybody to add new ships, weapons, missions or planets without even needing the source! Just check the description, there are links and stuff. I haven't clicked them yet, cuz I have my own projects to worry about, but you have a go at it.

Despite the way the economy works, as it is fixed for each planet, I found myself enjoying trading a lot more than other rpg's I've played, and, for once, the game didn't force me to carry an entire arsenal of weapons to avoid having a bad experience. I found this game extremely immersive, which is great inspiration for a sci-fi story, or something, if you're interested in writing.

However, one thing I cannot forgive this game for is it's writing. I mean, not in the whole game, mostly just one part in particular. Not even mostly, it's exactly just one part in particular. It's not necessarily a bad thing, nor did it ruin the game for me, it's just something I'm cherry picking because it really annoyed me at the time. SPOILERS IN THE NEXT BIT.

reviewText:
Its free, It has great Depth, its fairly pretty to play, Its still being developed and updated.

Really do you need to know more just to pick it up and give it a shot? Ok well fine.

Pros:

Ship Customization: There is a fairly large variety of ships, all of which have thier own purposes, pro's and cons. I havn't played around with all of them yet, but its pretty apparent after a few hours that there is no single ship that does it all the best, there will always be another ship that does something better then your current ship, weather thats hauling freight, or blowing stuff up, or carrying passengers.

Equipment Customization: Each ship is customizable as far as the type of engines, weapons, and sub systems your ship has. There is great fun to be had trying to optimize your ship while maintaining a functional balance... or you can just say screw balance and desighn a way way overpowered ship in one class, that sucks in everything else.

Missions: All the various missions in the game are tailored to your ship/fleet. This is great starting out, as you wont have kill/escort" missions dropping on your head that honestly your lil tiny freighter has no hope of completeing. Have a bunch of freighters/transports? You'll get alot of those missions. Have a fleet of fighters? Get combat missions.

Combat: Combat is tough
recommended: but very enjoyable to watch/participate in. There can be massive fleet engagements
hoursPlayed: or slow duel's and dances.\n\nFreedom: You can pretty much play how you want
voteText: though some ways are easier then others. Can even conquer planets if you desire

though the owning faction will be fairly upset with ou.

Still in development: The Game has a few rough points

reviewText:
Started as a captain, ended up as a commodore.
Great free game to play, clocked a good amount of hours flying, fighting and trading.

The Slate:
The game is still under development so the storylines are not yet complete, the onle playable one is the rebel/freeworlds story. There are a good amount of side quests for bounty hunting, escorting, and ferrying as well as trading.
The galaxy is pretty decent in size already, but I have high hopes on it growing and seeing more planets and factions.

Gameplay:
The game is very reminiscent of escape velocity, I noticed it is a lot easier to start of as a barge and make trade runs and buy more barges to increase your cargo. I really enjoyed the autopilot bits for landing and jumping to other systems, the auto firing I really appreciated since I wanted to be like those other ships and not fire every gun at the same time.

Wishes:
Faction specific ships, news, faction specific outfits, bigger galaxy, more factions, a steam workshop, junkyard systems, ship painting planets/stations. follow up quests or notes after helping people out, the ability to join a faction and fight as part of a fleet under a commander/work for corporations, after dominating a planet being able to shell out cash to upgrade infrastructure to add more ships, increase trade, increased population etc...

Cannot wait to see the game with more content in the future.

I can do a pretty thorough pro's/con's list, but let me summarize why I like Escape Velocity (EV). It didn't DRAW you into the game. I can't stress how refreshing that is.

In my experience, games that DRAW you into them, are only good for people who don't have things to do in the real world. Even many of the so-called casual games require you not be distracted.

I got through high school on EV, and now that I run private business, have two kids, and very little free time, it's nice to find a game that actually lets you play without costing you in the real world.

In thirty minutes, I wrote this guide, made 4 million credits on my trade route, fed my daughter, talked to my son about a book he is reading, and cleaned portions of the kitchen. A productive morning. On top of that, if I can focus on the game, a quick switch of ships, and I can Join the Navy!" and blast some scum."

Im not sure if this is a bug or what but i bought a fleet of ships after saving up for ages and taking out loans etc and then suddenly i lost a ship without even realising i had there was no notification or anything just when i checked it wasnt there so i spent and entire 4mil in credits for nothing and i still had to pay off a loan. I still dont even know what happened to it, maybe it was attacked by pirates but the least the game could have done is told me so i could protect it. :/ the game was fun up until that point when i gave up because of this\n

This game is great for several reasons.
1. It's nostalgic. It reminds me of playing awesome flash games when I was younger.
2. It fulfills your thirst for enterprise. I love games where you build up economy, especially when the storyline may effect that.
3. It's small, and took .2 seconds to download and install. It's simple but fun.
I reccomend this game to players who want to pass the time without human interaction.

I also very much appreciate the improvements to fleet management and the additions of passenger missions.\n\nIf you like EV, play this.

reviewText: I was a huge fan of Escape Velocity in the old days, and this feels like the sequel to Nova I always wanted.  Still a little short in the story department, this game has a solid foundation and a LOT of room to grow.

In short, if you grew up playing the escape velocity games like I did, this is the closest game to come along that I've seen to replicate those games.

Is it perfect?  No.  I don't like being able to jump out of a system from anywhere.  the game also feels like it's stuck in high speed mode.  It's almost impossible to pay off medium sized loans just by doing regular missions and cargo runs.

Things it improves upon:  I do like having an option to get a loan. I also like knowing the prices of commodities in another system. I like the combat system and the way the game handles combat and boarding.  I like how passengers are treated separately and aren't just more cargo.  These are all things I feel like would be natural progressions in a game series.

The fact that it's free means there's no reason not to try this game, even if you've never played an EV game before.

Pros:

- Late game is very great

Cons:

- Repeative

Endless Sky. It's most realistic debt simulator I've ever seen. You start with a spaceship of your choice, which you'll buy with... ehm... debt money. And that's how your adventure begins, to get rid of your debt! Yay!

The serious part starts here:

The game is very repetitive in the beginning. First thing you want to do is get rid of your debt and start earning money for yourself. It is very statisfying when you get rid of the debt, which isn't very easy. It can take many attempts to find a viable way to get rid of your debt. But after hours of transporting, you can gather your own fleet. Continue as teader/transporter or finally become a mercenary or pirate!

A 'practically endless' sci-fi -inspired sandbox with a distinctively classical gameplay... It kinda saddens me that this kind of game concepts are pretty much ignored by the AAA studios and publishers, because I'd love to see a game where I could do all of this in first person. (Star Citizen, maybe?)
Teh arbitrary list of pros and cons goes here:

Pros:
- An original sci-fi world with its own lore, locales, races, thingmagajigs etc. Lots of descriptions, random events and tiny detail you could admire for hours and hours...

- The game leaves the exploration and discovery to you and there's direct benefits as well as risks to it. I know its hard to achieve with the level of writing shown here, but I kinda wish there was a random map generator and/or more rogue-like elements for additional replay value.

-The learning/grinding curve feels rough and tedious at times, but it's never unfair other than in the way you'd expect it
to be. (You're a lone, debt-ridden pilot in space, anyone could be your enemy if you decide to make them one...)

-You can be a transporter or a merchant and moreover, it's profitable and compelling enough on its own, you never feel like the story or the gameplay is forcing any of the combat and conflict on you. (This is what practically every other sci-fi -themed, or rather, every other videogame is guilty of...)

-It's not like they forgot about conflict either, sure you can become a space pirate or a bounty hunter, even a scout if you will, but it's way more risky than being a merchant, and rightly so.

Cons:
- Combat is clunky, you feel like inertia is your main enemy, as you and your opponent spin around in awkward circles  briefly barraging each other with your weapons before flying off in separate directions... (Most of of the time is easier to avoid fighting all together, and true enough, transporters and freighters are not even designed for combat, but having it in there, I'd love if it was a bit more accessible to a new player, since I don't feel any sort of motivation to try and learn about combat in its current form.)

- Everything is ready for you.." This is kind of hard to pin down and sure

reviewText: Okay where do i begin well I'll start by describing it. This game is a 2D sci-fi game where you start off buying your first ship (after taking a sizeable loan just over 420k) you meet people in spaceports that give you quests you can choose your career of a trader,cruise ship captain,bounty hunter, freedom fighter, pirate, the list goes on. It's really dependant on your style of play. I opted to be a frieghter captain contracting my services for stable income and occasionally disabling small pirate craft and taking all their equipment. After awhile you pay off your loan and really your story depends on where you head off too. Shortly after my first mission I took a contract that took my south of the starting area and as i delivered my cargo i checked the spaceport and ended up being recruited by some of the free fighters to observe some systems. I further assisted them recieving a nice profit for good work nothing too bad just a smuggling of a person here and there. Overall the missions you get are well written in my opinion as well as some of your responces (I did the karate move for kicks fyi). The ship and module variaty seemed quite low at first untill i realized duh your not gonna have a planet selling every ship variaty. I started exploring and bam many new ships and modules were discovered. However the UI for the modules could use a little more clarity ( thought i might sell my ship by selling a module at first) but after about 15-30 minutes you get the hang of it. So for a free game 10/10 there is no downside to downloading this game since it's so small. If i had to pay for this game i might pause since the combat seems a little harsh some times (but hey i was a freighter not a fighter so i cant judge to harshly) still if they asked under 5$ it would still be reasonable the universe is quiet well crafted. Why are you still reading this hit the download button and play it now! STOP READING AND PLAY NOW!!!
Close to paying off debt. Go to a safe guarded galaxy. Pirates shoot me down. lost everything. Died 20 more times, smashed my hands till they were bloody and still had fun.

If you ever played the original Escape Velocity and lost too many hours of your life to it. Well, this is just like it, only with countless little tweaks and improvements. The mortgage system adds an extra element of real life as well as the whole loan system and galactic credit score.

In the beginning you will get blown up, a lot, but like EV, you're saved at each landing.

Also, as it can be a struggle at times, but I like that. But just as things seem bad, I started getting bounty hunter missions. So my weird custom city-ship is finally seeing some real combat. And, if you need money, try disabling larger pirate ships and steal all their best outfits and cargo.

The only control missing, unless I haven't found it yet is EV's old auto pilot for combat.
loved the game (still do) showed it to all my friends i rate 12/10\nyup its more than just 10
Excellent game. Creating a plug-in and playing based on that is even more fun.
Fantastic little game. It's sort of like a simple singleplayer EVE online. I usually do missions while watching streams or studying.

Suprisingly fun & addicting... The variety of customization you can do, from weapons, thrust, cooling, energy etc. is Immense - I remember spending 15-20 minutes deciding on what to put on my ships, or plot out the course across the galaxy to acquire the parts (on later part you can even attempt to board and strip alien tech, some are very useful stuff that can't be bought anywhere else) . And the storyline, ooh man, rich, engaging, clean story-telling, with enough twist and turn to keep the player surprised - [slight spoiler alert] My favorite part of the story is when I entered a star system with my fleet prepped expecting a full out fight to the death, but just you find out your enemies" are just confused about what's going on as you are [end spoiler]. Probably everything I can ask for in a game this scale.\n\nOne big problem though: How do I pay for this game?"
Excellent free game. Casual enough to run in the background of other activities, but addicting enough to keep me entertained for hours. Probably worth at least $5, but it's free! 10/10.

Starting ships are more than a bit underwhelming, and the early game economy is not very forgiving once you factor in fuel prices at each port....overall Id give this a 4/10.....looks nice, but has a long way to go.

I played Escape Velocity for years and just happen to find this game while browsing Steam.  It has scratched that EV itch and then some.  It's a great game and I hope that the Dev continues to expand on it.

Enjoying the game so far. It's an exploration/trading/ship shooting game. Not too hard to make money and not too horribly grindy. Fairly easy to use controls and graphics are decent for 2D (top-view).

This simple, yet addicting, little game brings nostalgic memories of actually working to prosper in video games; in this case, the payoff is very satisfying and makes the grinding well worth it.\nA very enthusiatic 9.5/10 from me.
This game is an amazing rebot of an old classic.\nWith a few more tweaks, and some upgrades to sound, mechanics and storyline, this could be one of the greatest reboots of all time.\n

if you like Escape velocity, this is basically it. im pretty thrilled about it. i hated that EV games just kind of lingered and disappeared. this is the same idea, but it looks nicer, and it has gameplay improvements over EV Nova. jumps don't require moving away from planets as that is just a time hog, and auto pilots will assist your landing to make things less frustrating. the map could be bigger, and as mods are made for it, im sure it will become the community game it should be. i think you are gonna love it, and you can't beat free. you don't like their free game? thats your fault not theirs. they give and you just take, like a filthy horse person. just give it a try. you'll see its as good as you could possibly hope for, and likely to get better once the community gets its hands on it. hell i already made my own mod with 2 new planets, it took me like 30 minutes. more dedicated people will likely whip up a full star wars mod in like 2 weeks, by just converting the images and scripts from the EV mods.

This game is very well made, but the gameplay can be difficult, and the tutorials are a little confusing. Overall, I recomend this game to any person interested in space age rpg's. The story is well written from what I have managed to see so far, I would rate this a solid 7/10.
Hallelujah, Escape Velocity is back! I can't wait to see where this game goes with contributions, but it's already a pretty solid follow-up to one of my favorite series of all time.

What can I say I played 13 hours straight when I first downloaded this! Great ship designs hopefully updates will come out for more ships! (P.S. It gets laggy when you have like 200+ ships around you.) Would recommend. 10/10
